Medical engineer Ryan Stone works feverishly to repair her shuttle hundreds of miles from the Earth's atmosphere after a catastrophic collision with orbiting debris damages her likelihood of reentry and survival in Gravity.

Watching this movie you want to use terms like cool and awesome because, technically speaking, this movie is magnificent and awe-inspiring to watch. The purely computer generated images of the vast abyss of space, a cusp of Earth's surface and a gleaming sun astronomically farther away in the background is spectacularly beautiful. With limited knowledge of space and aeronautics, this is about as real as I can imagine, though I know experts disagree - I'm looking at you Neil deGrasse Tyson. Beyond the aesthetically pleasing set design, I find little else in this picture remarkable.

While beautiful, its artistry in scenery makes the film detached and voyeuristic. Gravity starts almost immediately with the collision and has very minimal character development initially. These factors led me to be unable to suspend disbelief and truly immerse myself in the story nor become invested in the main character's survival. Further, the plot is tired and worn out. Several movies of a similar plot precede Gravity - which is basically a disaster survival story in space (most notably 2001: A Space Odyssey and Apollo 13, among others).

I can't help but imagine the executives at Warner Bros. and how this film came to be:

We need a hit film, a huge money maker, but something new, fresh!

CGI, its all about that CGI, that's what sells movies...we've just got to take it to the next level!

Yeah, but we've done just about everything on earth...

That's the problem! On Earth...space! Brilliant, and we will make it in Imax, get even more money for the tickets.

Yeah, but we have to get actors that get a huge draw in the box office.

Who is hot right now?

Robert Downey Jr.? Angelina Jolie?

Nah, Jolie has something scheduled already. Downey probably won't want to do it, he's too improvisational, won't be his style.

We could get Clooney? Everybody loves George.

But what about the girl? Who won best actress last year? Jennifer Lawrence? Too young. Meryl Streep? Too old. Natalie Portman? Not likeable enough. How 'bout Sandra Bullock? Sandy will probably do it.

But who is going to take the risk of making this movie? It could tank. Well, he will have to be a relative unknown, but made a hit before, international, so hungry to break into mainstream Hollywood. Alfonso Cuar√≥n? I think he wanted to be an astronaut when he grew up. Isn't he shopping a script set in space?

And the rest is history...

In all seriousness, the movie never connected with me, while visually brilliant, it is lacking in all other regards. If you are into special effects and the sheer technical breadth of the undertaking of that crew, whom I commend, then I suggest this movie.

One of the most talked about trailers of the year has been the two-minute trailer for "Gravity" that features Sandra Bullock and George Clooney floating in space. In the two-minutes, we see a brief intense and desperate moment in the span of a long movie where Bullock's character, Ryan Stone, tries to grab hold of anything and everything as her situation spins out of control. Many thought, "Is that it? Is that what the movies about?" or, "Two people in space. That movie looks silly." Well, "Gravity" is far from silly.

On the other hand, what you see in that trailer is exactly what you will have in store when you sit down to watch it. It is exactly what the movie is about and there are only two people in the entire movie. You will also see an amazingly well crafted, intelligent, exquisite and visceral space journey that possibly puts all other movies of the same vain to shame.

Regardless of what you think of the trailer, you couldn't take your eyes off of it for two-minutes and that is exactly the way the full 90-minute movie is. "Gravity" takes you into space and treats you as if you were a tag-along for Ryan Stone's journey. The direction of Alfonso Cuaron is spot on, if not for a few minor moments of over-dramatization.

Cuaron may be most well known for his direction of "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban", but he also directed "Children of Men" and one of my personal favorites, "A Little Princess". This is a phenomenal achievement for Cuaron and for the history and future of film-making. If you've ever desired to go to space, this may be as close as you will ever get. "Gravity" rings authentic and it is exactly what movies are all about, taking you, the viewer along for a journey that you can't get in your ordinary life.

I would have scored the film higher but I felt events in the movie were a little cliche with what seemed like everything going wrong along Dr. Stone's (Sandra Bullock) journey. Overall it is a really good film and praise must be given to Alfonso Cuar√≥n for directing this, I think I would enjoyed it more in 3D but still an excellent film.

This film is a technical marvel in addition to being a masterclass of suspense that will transport you to a world that is vaguely familiar from documentaries, but now much more intimate yet empty.  
Gravity begins with a sustained shot that feels like it is about 20 minutes long,( I heard elsewhere it is 17.)  No matter how long it is your jaw will be on the floor wondering how this was pulled off. Everything on the screen must be CG, but it just doesn't look like it at all.  And the length of the take helps sell the illusion.  
As the movie opens, a spacewalk is taking place by three astronauts to repair the Hubble telescope.  At the same time Russia decides to destroy one of it's own satellites, starting a chain reaction that sends debris right at our astronauts.  Soon after disaster strikes and the only astronauts left alive are medical engineer Bullock and veteran astronaut George Clooney.  Bullock soon earns her stripes, surviving crisis after crisis trying to find a way to get back to Earth.
All of the action scenes are amazing, although credibility is strained with how resilient Bullock's character is; given this is supposed to be her first space mission.  That will only be at the back of your mind because of how engrossing and absolutely gripping all of the action is in this movie.  
The suspense and the characters are strong enough in this film without having to add a subtext, but this is what unfortunately happens.  Bullock is given a backstory about how her daughter died in a freak accident and now she needs to be reborn and find herself again, which plays itself out during quiet moments.  It just wasn't necessary to shoehorn this in, I think the film could have been just as strong without it.  We are already connected to the characters through the situations presented. Grade: 9
though far from original, and its dialogue less equal in strength to its impressive visuals, performances and score, this movie still earns the right to be remembered.

I was one of the people VERY excited to watch this movie when I first heard about it. It looked so tense and crazy to watch. And fortunately Gravity doesn't disappoint.
Dr. Ryan Stone is in the worst position any human being could be in. Trapped in space with limited oxygen, what on earth can she do? (pun intentioned)
Now when I say Gravity met my expectations, I mean that it delivered the visuals I expected, which are AMAZING! I seriously regret not seeing this in 3-D, even if there was the clique I AM REACHING TOWARD THE CAMERA moment in the beginning. You can tell just how much effort was put into making the visual effects look real.
I also expected a not so interesting story with the visuals, which is also what I got. And I understand that this is difficult to pull off since a) these visuals will outshine almost any story given to it and b) our lead Ryan faces a problem lack of oxygen; therefore she SHOULDN'T be talking in space that much with George Clooney's character about her past. Yet she does so anyways! This would be acceptable had we learned more about Ryan. And what did we learn about her? Her son died...that's about it. 
So despite these problems Gravity definitely deserves the attention it's been getting. I love these visuals and the movie's tense moments are very exciting to watch unfold.

Firstly, let me give credit where credit where credit is due.

The effects used in the movie are definitely stunning and the acting is top notch.
But brilliant effects, camerawork and acting does not automatically translate into a good movie. 
This movie could have been shortened down to 30 minutes and they would still have been able to include everything that happens in this movie into one.

There is only so much floating in space and constantly inhaling and exhaling I can put up with.

And the plot.....What IS the plot? There is not enough garbage trucks in the world to keep up with how RECYCLED this plot is. 

Basically: something bad happens, Sandra stressfully goes to a different space pod or station or whatever and solves the problem before another bad thing happens. Just rinse and repeat for an extremely tedious 1 hour and 31 minute movie that could have easily been a ride at Universal Studios. 

Spoiler alert. Clooney's death was emotional, but it had been executed far greater in the vastly underrated Europa Report movie.

By the way, spoiler alert. Sandra Bullock would not be bloody walking after she crash landed on Earth. You DO know that after spending so much time in zero-G your legs would have adapted to the gravity in the Earth's atmosphere and that adding such a great amount of pressure to your legs after CRASH landing would mean your legs would just collapse? *sigh* 

Far too many people subconsciously believe that a simulation in space immediately makes for a perfect movie.  It doesn't. It's just pretty to look at. Nothing more.

Among critics, this film has a 9/10 average rating, which is rare on rottentomatoes.com. That is why I went to the theaters to see it in the first place. Personally, I came away disappointed. And no, it's not because I was over hyped, but rather the film itself was/is overrated. It was largely empty and hallow, touched with a few religious overtones. Beyond such overtones, it doesn't have much meaning. Like, who the heck cares? 

Now, its worth speculating why this turned out to be a disappointing film. And I think its pretty obvious, much like in many other Hollywood productions. The director is largely concerned with providing a purely technical experience, which he sure did. But that is not what makes a film great. What makes a great film? Personally, its simply one that is able to speak of and criticize social conditions, which cannot be achieved in Gravity, because its premise is purely abstract.

Bullock gives a solid performance and Gravity is well worth seeing.

I was surprised that I actually enjoyed this film. Why? Because modern Sci-Fi, especially the last half dozen years or so, is typically awful.

Gravity is visually amazing and a huge technical feat in the world of movies.  It was a long time ago since I saw a sci-fi movie that brought something new to the genre, and Gravity has a lot of "on the edge of your seat" moments.

That being said, it is not what holds for a complete movie.  The story of space debree destroying everything around Sandra Bollock which forces her to return back to earth doesn't hold a lot storywise.  Normally I would feel a lot for a main character in desperation.  But this one is not very interesting, no matter how well she plays it.  Her character is almost to whiney and irritating.  So I'm left with a series of cliffhangers that is supposed to transfer me from point a to point b.

I still hold to that Gravity is visually amazing and deserved all the technical awards that it received.  But otherwise, it comes across as another cotastrophe movie, this time taking place in outer space.  Very entertaining, very thin, but basically a perfect Saturday matinee flick.

I know that I get excited every time I see a new movie and tend to over-exaggerate its virtues. However, I am not exaggerating when I say that "Gravity" is the type of no holds barred cinematic experience that affects you on so many levels: visual, physical, emotional, spiritual. It is the type of movie that takes what would seem to be a boring concept and turns it into an existential trip that takes us to the extremes of what the human mind- and body can handle, all set on the backdrop of outer space. A truly remarkable accomplishment.

I was personally shocked by the academy attention this film got. While it did have the boring and slow story that the academy tends to love, this film for me, was reaching. With a lead character who didn't have the charisma or powerful personality it takes to carry a film with such little dialogue. I'm a dialogue-lover, and this films lack there of really turned me off. The makers undoubtedly focused on the spectacular sights, and not... well, anything else. It's like they said, "let's see how pretty we can make this movie"..."can anyone think of a pretty setting?", "oh, space you say?... good idea"... and from there they wrote your run of the mill "space-mission-gone-wrong" film, and the deep space was so mesmerizing, they managed to sneak it last fans and critics and rode all the way to the Oscars. Maybe I'm so harsh on this one because I was picturing a much better film. If you saw it in an Imax theater than you most likely lived the film. But to me a truly good film is good no matter what screen you watch it on.

Moved by a top-notch script full of beautiful messages, stunning performances from Sandra Bullock and George Clooney, breathtaking visual effects and an outstanding score by Steven Price, "Gravity" not only can be labeled as the best film of 2013, but also as one of the best space-themed films ever made and as one of the best films of all time as well.

Fortunately, Gravity received critical acclaim and was a commercial success, but despite any criticisms against its scientific commentary and how "factual" it is, I can honestly say it's worth all the hype surrounding it, like the stars surrounding its main characters. 

An epic 3-D experience and an artistic marvel in terms of its cinematography and use of CGI (computer-generated imagery) to exceed its atmosphere into visual storytelling, Gravity happens to be even more suspenseful, thanks to a convincing performance in one of Sandra Bullock's most memorable roles to date and its claustrophobic camera angle, concept, and visual imagery, as well as its emotionally compelling subplots.

Maybe it's not 100 percent successful in achieving the attention of its target demographic and beyond, but Gravity certainly excels beyond that of a James Cameron feature-film for the fact that it's not overwhelmed by narcissistic filmmaking and that it actually uses its setting in space to become one of the most grandiose visual masterpieces to come in a long, long while.

Pros: it's an original film, that taps into a possible scenario that everyone can imagine which taps into our sense of fear and thrills. Furthermore, the sound effects and visuals are great

As a dedicated geek with a space fetish more than four decades old I was hamstrung by my knowledge of space travel so Gravity fell flat on it's face from my perspective. The whole premise of the movie is exceedingly unlikely and the special effects are all about wowing the audience rather than accurately depicting what a space accident might really be like. As a result I just wound up rolling my eyes a lot. 

It's too bad, too. They could have made basically the same movie without turning the sky into a clown car of debris. A single softball sized chunk of metal could have easily caused the same level of destruction as was depicted in the movie, but as usual the need to pander to an audience that wants gasoline explosions and gunfights won out over good storytelling.

Look... if you don't suffer from TMI syndrome this might be a good movie. I can't say because the technical inaccuracies made it impossible for me to suspend my disbelief. I was just not able to get any sense of immersion from it at all. 

But hey... if you like action flicks or have a thing for one of the headliners and you can get past the silliness and just enjoy the spectacle go ahead and give it a watch. You'll get to see Sandra Bullock in a wet T-shirt and that alone pretty much justifies the cost of the rental.

Film reviewers usually write a short synopsis of the film at this point but I choose to give as little info as possible in order to maintain your enjoyment of the film.  I will tell you that the story is about a routine repair in space which is interrupted and forced to abort.  Dr Ryan Stone and Matt Kowalsky are forced to find a way back to earth, but things are rarely that easy and this film is no different.  The storyline is a bit far fetched after the accident in space but the photography is amazing.  From a nerds point of view, the International Space Station (ISS Zarya) travels around the earth at approx 17,000 miles per hour.  In order for the Explorer space shuttle to maintain the same distance it too would have to be travelling at 17,000 (and occasionally correct its orbit) yet both appear almost motionless (watch the earth below).  If you want a real-life view of the ISS as it orbits the earth every 93 minutes then visit http://n2yo.com/space-station.  That said, the film has excellent CDG footage and the short accompanying film on the DVD showing the inuit (who talks to Bullock on the radio), his wife, baby and working dogs in Greenland (or is it Alaska?) links to the film well.  If none of this makes any sense then watch the film.  I sure you'll enjoy it.

Gravity is not really a movie, it's more of a cinematic experience . When watching the film, it really makes you feel like you're in space. That experience takes up more than half the movie and really what it give us is enough. I'll jjust say something that might ruffle a few feathers amoung the film community: Gravity is a whole lot better than James Cameron's Avatar. 

Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock)  is on her very first shuttle mission in space with veteran astronaut Matt (George Clooney). Something of course goes horribly wrong. The shuttle is destroyed and the astronauts must find a way to get back to Earth.  Like I said before, Gravity is mostly an experience of what it could be like in Space. Obviously I'm not an astronaut so I have no idea if anything in the film is scientifically inaccurate or whatever. The Visual Effects in this are just astounding. Unlike Avatar, Gravity doesn't look like you're watching a computer. It really feels like you're with these characters in this disaster of a mission. 

The acting here is just fantastic in this film, in particular Sandra Bullock's. For more than half the movie, she has to carry the plot all by herself. And you know what? She Does it very well. It was almost like watching Tom Hanks in Castaway. This movie really shows how great an actress Bullock is and I wish more people in the general movie going public saw that. However, I'll just say it right now: I have no idea what George Clooney is doing in this movie. For most of the time, all he does is chew the scenery as much as possible. George Clooney is one of those actors who whenever I watch him, I don't see a character. All I see is George Clooney act like an astronaut. 

Besides George Clooney acting like himself, there is another big problem with this movie. It has a lot of slow moments. I mean yeah there's a lot of action an destruction, but there are times when the film feels like it's in slow motion. I came very close to dosing off once or twice. I think maybe if the film had really great character development not just with Bullock but Clooney too. I mean the characters aren't bad, it's just we don't get much sense of their identities as human beings. Maybe if the film started on Earth and we got to see these people's lives before going to space it wouldn't be an issue. 

Besides those problems, Gravity really is a great movie. Is it one of my favorites? No not really. But I would watch it again. It has great atmosphere, great visual effects, great acting from Sandra Bullock and the film is worth watching at least twice. It didn't win 7 Oscars for nothing did it?

They say, in space, no one can hear you scream.

Unless you're Sandra Bullock.

Old Sandy screamed her way through most of Gravity and I heard every spine-tingling second of it.  In surround sound.  And 3D.  It was epic.

Space huh.  Geeeeez.  Louise.  Hectic stuff.  I've never been, but those I know who have say it's mental.  Gravity certainly gives that impression and even if I had been contemplating a trip to space, I'd probably reassess it now.  Consider something a bit more low-key.  Micronesia is meant to be nice.

In Gravity, Bullock plays Dr Ryan Stone, a first time astronaut sent to space to apply her expertise in biomedical engineering.

"Why do you have a boy's name?" asks her team leader, veteran spacewalker Matt Kowalski (played by George "Everything's going to be ok" Clooney).  Fair question.  "Because my father only wanted a boy," answers Ryan.

Oh.

It's just a glimpse into Ryan's sad life back home but enough to make you realise why she'd agree to leave earth behind and go to space, where she's more out of place than Uranus....

Unfortunately for Ryan, life in space has also got its shit moments.  Before you've finished your choc-top, the shuttle the astronauts are working from is struck by a storm of space junk, sending Ryan and Matt tumbling away into the universe like a couple of tic-tacs.  Space, as it has it, is extremely large.  Ryan and Matt have limited oxygen, pretty clumsy costumes and no map.  Oh, and the meteor shower is on its way back round.  All signs point to giving up on life and spending whatever time is left filming a zero gravity Harlem Shake so at least the world will have something to remember you by.

But you don't need to have seen Speed to know that Sandra don't just give up.  In fact, the closest she's ever come to it was after Miss Congeniality 2: Armed and Fabulous.

And that, remarkably, is about all you need to know.

Other than this: Gravity was, in my opinion, the best film of 2013.  It is one of those rare movies that can redefine a genre and become the benchmark.  Like The Shining for horror; The Notebook for romance; and Titanic for comedy.

The visuals are spacetacular.  At times, Gravity feels more like a ride than a movie.  I like 3D in theory but Gravity is one of only three films that I've ever seen that are truly enhanced by that third dimension (Avatar and Life of Pi).

I'd be lying if I said I didn't try to touch things.

Sandra and George are well cast and will win awards.  No one has ever said anything about whether or not you can hear George Clooney's voice in space.  You'll be pleased to know that you can.  And it's just as dulcet.

Gravity grabs you from the start and holds onto you for a very trim, very compact, very polished, very polite 90 minutes.  There's no fat on this film.  You don't walk away saying "that was awesome but it could have been half an hour shorter".  You walk away saying "that was awesome and hey, shit, it's only 9 and Timezone's still open, let's play air hockey."

Now that you've read this review to the end, I want you to do me, and you, one more favour.  Put down your computer, go outside and look up at the sky.  Go on, just do it.  Look at all of it.  Up there.  Look at it and think about how big space is and how small you are.  If it's night where you are, look at the stars, all of them, sparkling and blazing up there as if they were massive, luminous spheres of plasma held together by their own gravity.  If it's daytime, just look at the sun.  Shh, go on, just do it this once, one time won't hurt you.

We do a lot of things these days, in this crazy modern world.  What we don't do enough is look at space.  So go look at the sky.  What have you got to lose?  At worst, you'll get bat piss in your eye.  At best, you'll see George Clooney.

Rarely do "space" movies truly capture the full feel of existing beyond the confines of an atmosphere. Some take liberties with technology not yet available, as in The Fifth Element. More scientifically accurate films such as Apollo 13 place an emphasis on characters and relationships on Earth, distracting the audience from the experience of orbit.

Gravity is as close to outer space as many of us may come. Director Alfonso Cuar√≥n paints astronauts on a deep, boundless canvas, enveloping the audience in the vast expanse which lacks air, life, and sound. The camera documents the movements of these space walkers not as we would in a studio, as we sometimes get with zero-gravity flicks, but instead with a lighter touch, allowing the audience to join their astronaut counterparts in their orbit.

These astronauts have come to the last frontier to fix the Hubble Space Telescope, and Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) is an engineer who was rushed onto the mission because of her expertise. This routine mission is led by Matt Kowalski (George Clooney), who has a dozen stories for every flight he's ever led (many, we assume). Plans for a quick and clean return to Earth are thrown askew when debris is plunged towards the astronauts and their ride home, as seen in the previews. Gravity, and solutions to their problems, are not easy to come by anymore. And we don't just have a front row seat: we're practically taking the shrapnel with them.

Cuar√≥n reaches beyond creating a film, and produces instead an effervescent experience. Point-of-view shots can often be gimmicky, but are executed precisely when necessary inGravity. Honestly, the cinematography is such that the entire ride seems to be in first person, where these POV shots merely accentuate the emotions of Dr. Stone.Another reason the audience is thrust into outer space is thanks to Art Director Andy Nicholson, who creates an Earth so massive, it looms larger than even an IMAX screen can capture.

Gravity is unlikely to grab any writing nominations, nor many nods for acting (with the exception of Bullock). However, this film is a visual marvel, on par with 2011's Avatar. The story is simple, real, and tangible, and portrays space in a way that has even impressed Buzz Aldrin (see link below).

Go see this movie, and do it fast. The experience will not be the same at home, no matter how expansive the theater system installed in your basement. In fact, (and I swear I'm not working for a distributor) shell out the extra money to view Gravity in 3D and/or IMAX. While 3D is generally a detriment to good cinema, the setting of this film lends itself to  an elaborate and convincing use of the technology, and is well worth the extra change.

Gravity isn't so much just a movie, but a ride that will leave you breathless.

The movie stars Sandra Bullock as Dr. Ryan Stone and George Clooney as Matt Kowalsky. When Stone is on her first shuttle mission in space with Matt, the whole thing takes a turn for the worst as a shower of broken debri comes flying their way, destroying everything in its path. Stone and Kowalsky are the only ones left alive, tied only to each other, struggling to get to safety in the horrifying blackness of space. Sandra Bullock does an amazing job acting, and the close-up camera shots help to create a tight, dangerous, terrifying feel to the movie.

This is not an exciting film. This is barely a film. It's very pretty to look at, but is that really enough to garner seven awards and nearly endless praise? Apparently so. I'm in the minority, clearly, but I'm not alone, so here's why I hated Gravity.

Sandra Bullock's character should never have been an astronaut. At best, she is a panicky dipstick in distress who either yammers or stutters her way through much of this film and seems to have no idea how things work or what to do when things break down. It seemed like she had no training at all.

The silence is not terrifying. I don't care how many reviewers just couldn't wait to use the phrase "deafening silence", the silence is NOT terrifying. The silence COULD have been terrifying if there was any real threat or I cared about the character at all, but unlike Aliens there were no monsters lurking in the hallways. It was just Bullock vs. her own jittery dumbness. I didn't care if she made it back alive or not. Clooney's character didn't last long enough to be developed, so I didn't care about him (honestly, Clooney's character was just George Clooney playing George Clooney in an astronaut suit) and the only other character, who we only see in a couple shots, died even sooner than that. We're not given any real background on anyone, there is no real story and honestly some of the physics were just embarrassingly wrong. 

If you haven't watched this film yet, but you're curious, just do this instead: 
go to Google, find some amazing looking images of space. Now imagine Sandra Bullock, in a spacesuit, floating around in those images and saying "no no no okay okay" over and over, flailing her arms and breaking things (and barking like a dog in one scene. Yes, I'm serious.) You just watched Gravity.

An absolutely extraordinary film to say the least. To play with the notion of paranoia tends to be the clich√© that runs with thrillers, but what truly set this movie apart from the rest is the heart-pounding quietness of the film. When it's quiet, it's quiet. You can hear every breath you take and can feel the tension in the room among the rest of the audience. Then all of a sudden the film hits you with utter calamity; pure chaos that rocks the nerves and keeps your attention focused on the screen. So much so that you'll practically fall off of your seat! Yes this film may have its flaws, and it may lag on a little during the silent moments, but in the end it's a very satisfying film to watch and definitely worth your time.

While watching Gravity, you'll probably feel that you're watching something new.

Clearly there are familiar elements in the movie. Disasters, like space are well-trodden themes in film. But they've never been approached in the same way that Gravity does. It's a perfect storm of innovative camera animation, lighting, acting, visual effects and audio design that all come together to compliment an interesting script and developed characters.
The result is one of the most compelling science fiction movies ever made, which is helped extraordinarily by the focus of the film. Sandra Bullock plays Dr. Ryan Stone, a new astronaut who is paired up with the veteran Matt Kowalski after their mission inevitably goes bad. It's an interesting dynamic to watch unfold and both actors impress despite the limitations that the movie placed on them. Clooney especially left me desperately wanting more of his character, and I can't help but feel that was intentional given the development of Bullocks character later on in the movie. Cuar√≥n also gives Bullock a lot of alone time on screen and she delivers what can only be described as a master class in using body language to convey emotions.

Considering how action heavy the film is, I was surprised by just how much I learnt about, and came to care about both characters. That's an impressive feat given that by modern standards the film is fairly short with a 90 minute run-time.

Speaking of action, I do not feel that I am exaggerating when I say that the high-octane scenes in Gravity are among the most tense sequences I have ever seen. This is where Cuar√≥ns now infamous use of long shots has been put to good use, and he takes every chance he gets to move and contort the camera in every way he can imagine. The fact that many of these scenes involve no cuts whatsoever drew me into the action without even realizing the presence of such a device, and everything is expertly mixed to Steven Prices heart-pumping score.

However these long takes are also used in a lot of the quieter moments in the film. Here too the continuous shots are used with surprising maturity, even considering who's creating them. Some of the best symbolism in the film comes as a direct result of how natural the movement is, and although some of it admittedly feels forced it's always integrated into the story well and when done right gives a whole new meaning to some of the shots.Quite frankly, you could (and I will) discuss Gravity for hours, but when the credits rolled and the lights came up I was simply in shock. It's a genuinely jaw-dropping experience which showcases everything that makes film great, and I really can't offer any better praise.

Nothing can defeat a space adventure that Gravity is. Gravity is visually-stunning. Sandra Bullock and George Clooney are spectacle in this cinematic experience where viewers feel they are part of the suspense. Especially in IMAX 3D. There have been several space movies that have captivated me, and at first with Gravity I was worried about it at first with the fact it is only ninety-two minutes. Where as most space movies go like two hours flat. However, it was a ninety-two minute thrill ride that I will have to experience again once it re-releases in IMAX January 31st. It is so worth it even for a second experience if it has already been seen once.

The story follows a space mission involving two astronauts in space Ryan Stone (Bullock) and Matt Kowalski (Clooney). Both are traveling space together and working on space mechanics in space. However within minutes of their procedures, things start falling apart. Satellites crashing, metal objects flying everywhere, and the home base getting destroyed. This leaves only Stone and Kowalski to find a way to survive so many stories high into space with probably very little or maybe even know help. In IMAX the suspense feels real, and you feel like literally you are joining them in the process of trying to survive.

I was blown away by this movie. I am a fan of many space movies like Apollo 13, ET, 2001: A Space Odyssey, and many more. It makes you look back at these space films wondering how space can be. It especially makes you think about what would actually happen if you could go to space in your life. How would you prepare? What can possibly go wrong? Gravity leaves you asking yourself all of these questions and actually makes the film become a more inviting experience when it gets even more suspenseful.

This is  Alfonso Cuaron's tenth installment. I remember the most previous sci-fi movie he directed was back in the year 2006 and the film was Children of Men. For the editing he had his editor who edited his film Children of Men to edit Gravity. That editor is Emmanuel Lubezki. I will say honestly the editor deserves credit for editing this roller coaster ride of a movie. He made the space scenes so visual and was able to capture a variety of facial expressions of Sandra Bullock. Those facial expressions make audience feel that we can feel the emotions of the danger that Bullock's character is experiencing.

Do they make it out of space alive? If you have not seen it Find out and see it for yourself. Three and a half stars. It is now playing in 3D for a limited time but if you really want the experience it returns to IMAX January 31. Do not miss it.

Directed by Alfonso Cuar√≥n (Y Tu Mam√° Tambi√©n (2001), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004) and Children of Men (2006)), this has been a pet project of Cuar√≥n for a while, which he wrote with his son Jon√°s Cuar√≥n. It took a lot of time and effort to get this film made, as well as some groundbreaking special effects, and it's a very eerie and atmospheric thriller set in space. Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) is on her first mission into space on the Space Shuttle Explorer, with veteran astronaut Matt Kowalski (George Clooney), who is on his final mission. While on a routine mission doing repairs to the Hubble Telescope, they're hit by fast moving debris which destroys the rig they're working on, and Stone ends up flying into space with little oxygen, about to come to terms with her death, she's saved by Kowalski, who has a jet pack. They make their way to the International Space Station, so they can get an escape capsule back to Earth, but they don't have a lot of time to do it before the debris orbits Earth. It's a different kind of space film, it's not science fiction, it's science fact, as Cuar√≥n did his science homework before filming started. It requires patience and the open vistas of space with the majesty of Earth behind them is beautiful to look at. How they did the weightless scenes is worth wondering

Gravity was directed by Alfonso Cuar√≥n. It was written by Alfonso Cuar√≥n and Jon√°s Cuar√≥n. It's a Suspense movie. This movie lasts one hour and thirty one minutes. It was released in October 23, 2013. 

The main topic of the story is two astronauts who go to mission and lose all connection with the Earth and so all chance of rescue. The main characters are Dr. Ryan Stone, who is played by Sandra Bullock and veteran Matt Kowalsky who is played by George Clooney. 
Entire story takes place in the infinite and unforgiving realm of deep space. 

The summary is: 
it is the first expedition aboard a space shuttle for dr Ryan stone . She accompanies Matt Kowalsky . During a flight disaster , the two astronauts lose the control of the shuttle. They find themselves alone, without contact with the ground , left to themselves. At the end of the film we learn that only Dr. Ryan Stone Is back to earth.

The good point is that throughout the movie the viewer believe the two astronauts return live from this adventure. However, for some it may seem a bit long and ennyant as the the movie is essentially based on plans with the two astronauts trying to survive. 

I found this movie very exciting, which is why I recommend it to all people who love suspense and emotions.

Visually stunning, brilliantly directed film, with an Oscar worthy performance from Sandra Bullock. Written and Directed by Alfonso Cuaron, this epic sci-fi thriller stars Sandra Bullock as Dr. Ryan Stone, a medical engineer who happens to be on her first space mission when it just so happens to be debris from a satellite that crashes, allowing her to drift into space where our movie begins. This movie may be the closest thing to a perfect movie I have ever seen. With one hell of a great score from Steven Price, and Gorgeous visual effects, Gravity may be the most stunning space movie we have had ever. Not to be forgotten in this movie is George Clooney, as he has a somewhat smaller role, than we are usually use to. For Gravity my score is:
5/5 or 10/10

Anybody with a thread of common sense knows somebody this anxious would never be sent into space. Then there's Clooneys character..... Life or death situations & he is using cheesy pickup lines & wise cracking? That might be ok during one or maybe two disasters, but every time?? 1st the disaster then a pause then a Clooney attempt at a sarcasticly witty remark.  I'm scared of future big budget Hollywood movies trying to repeat the same unwarranted success.  Go to a planetarium or watch a documentary if you want amazing images of the earth. Let's leave our theaters for actual story telling.

Gone to see this movie eight times in the theaters before it came out! Such a well done movie! through out the movie you will be on the edge of your seat. Gravity is thrilling, horrifying, and I think one of the best science fiction movies in years.

1. Script: The script of this movie is rather touchy since they are acting as professional astronauts and scientists. Not all of this movies viewers know science and space lingo, so that is a problem. But I think the director and script editors did a very good job at watering down the technical language to something we all as the viewers could understand. 

2. Visual Effects: There are many graphically challenging hurdles of "filming" in space.  With the visual effects most of the acting took place in anti-gravity chambers coated in a green screen effect. In order to make this movie appeasing to all these space nerds the landscape of outer space had to be NASA good. I feel like the visual effects were outstanding and exceeded my expectations!

3. Actors/Actresses: The leading actors were the amazing Sandra Bullock and the classic George Cloony. I think the director Alfonso Cuar√≥n did a great job with choosing the main roles. Sandra Bullock did a rather amazing job acting in this movie, she fit the role rather well. George Cloony only had a short role but an important one, but he pulled it off well. 

4. The Story Line: The film is set during fictitious space shuttle mission STS-157. A medical engineer (Sandra Bullock) is put on a space shuttle mission. When tragedy strikes quick, she is the lone survivor. I think this is a timeless plot, put into a modern day type of setting. The only  thing I would fix is the short period of the time before the accident, but other than that it was awesome to watch.


5. Sound Effects: Most of the audience hasn't heard the loud crash of a shuttle taking off, nor have we had the chance to hear the silence of space. The sound editors wanted the sound to be heard as authentic as possible. I feel like they did, they made the effects sound clear and correct. Job well done.

You will not regret redbox'ing this movie, If your into Sci-fi, Thrillers, or even eye opening movies this is the film for your liking.
great in 3d.  a must see. real edge of your seat film

Gravity is a film that although I feel was and is overrated, still
manages to put together a good drama and with some breathtaking
effects, I would still recommend this to everyone. From a fine director
who has only really come from the shadows with this film to a duo that
share this film and well Ii must also mention they are two of the
biggest stars in Hollywood. With it's massive effects come massive
affects to the characters and with some speedy space junk to and escape
pods everywhere this film guarantees thrilling stuff. I felt this film
was strongly good, and here is why.

The story is a good one, not the finest I could think of but with some
great thrills and also spills, you are never not gripped to it. I felt
that the story at times did rely on it's effects and soppy stories of
home to fill in the gaps but nevertheless it is a solid story and even
if it is kind of simple still makes for pleasant viewing. The pace is
fast and big and you really don't know what will happen next, this one
reason rated this slightly higher as predicting what happens around her
is near impossible and all down to writing of a great writer and
director.

Sandra Bullock in the main role does a good job if not slightly over
dramatic one at times but manages to be great by the end. George
Clooney as back up seemed nearly too chilled to execute his role well
enough and just seemed to float around the entire film without trying
to do anything. With this there are only ever the two in it which makes
for cool viewing as you do in the end get to know quite a bit about
them even if the movie is only 91 minutes long, good stuff yet again
from Cuaron.

Alfonso Cuaron has to be one of the most underrate directors of our
time and I swear he can make any film better than it seems or just
generally better. His skill with the word is good too and some
dialogues I this although not always executed perfectly by the cast, is
great stuff and his choice of dialogue is intriguing at best. I can't
not mention the effects which are just massively and crazily big with
some sublime work done by the studio behind this, the entire thing
looks real and on such a scale too just wow, one of the best film for
effects I have ever seen seriously.

I do feel this film is overrated like I said, although Cuaron is
perfect and did deserve his Oscar for his work, I got annoyed with
Bullocks character and wasn't sure if that was just how Cuaron wanted
her to be or Bullock wasn't playing her right. I also will add that
although the drama is good and thrilling, this film offers very little
more in terms of anything and I cannot see why it is so highly reviewed
as it seriously is nothing special(well maybe the effects are but
effects don't make an entire movie flawless).

Those who enjoy space adventures will like it as Gravity is basically
what it says on the tin, she spins around in the earth's gravity a lot,
but it makes for good viewing though. I think Clooney fans may be
disappointed as we don't see loads of him and his screen time is just
not enough for him to save himself from his stale performance. I know I
sound like I hate it but it is actually worth a watch from anyone, no
matter what type of film you think you like, this can be enjoyed.

Overall I give this a high 7/10 meaning it is Strongly a Good film, it is very
near to being very good but certain factors don't allow it to move
upwards to there. Don't watch this and say you like it because all
critics say they do and because it won Oscars, see for yourself, I
didn't find it great but it was good and personal opinion is everything
here. One more thing is the score by Steven Price which I am not
kidding can make you heart beat faster in the more thrilling parts, and
also go see this in 3D if you want even more thrills than it already
gives.

Watching Gravity for the first time was amazing. And it always will be. This is one of those movies, for me, where the first time you watch it is the best time because you get all the excitement and emotions that you had with the most effect because you don't know what bone-chilling moment would come next (I honestly had no idea where I was going with that sentence). Some might say that all movies are like that but they aren't because they don't have those tense moments that really make you sit on the edge of your seat biting your nails, with the exception of a few. Anyway, I recommend you see Gravity in 3D. I know it not in theaters anymore for some people but there are such things as 3D TVs (not trying to make you spend money, I'm just saying). I urge you to watch it in 3D because it will be more realistic and actually make you feel like you're in space. This movie was the only one that I have ever seen that actually made me blink awkwardly and flinch when a piece of debris supposedly "hit the screen". Next I'd like to talk about the story. The story is pretty bland with not much to keep it going other than the characters and their goal to get home. But that doesn't really bother me mostly because it's not the story that actually keeps you invested in what's going on. It's the visual effects and acting. Without those, this movie would be about a 0.5/5 for being plain boring. But it's not like that, so that's what I want to talk about next: acting. We pretty much have two people acting for an entire movie with the exception of the voice on the radios and stuff. The main characters are Ryan Stone and Matt Kowalski played wonderfully by Sandra Bullock and George Clooney. They practically are the movie which is good because they are great actors. You really feel for them and want them to make it even though in the back of your head you know they might not. It's great and I love it.

So all in all, Gravity is a movie with great visual effects and superb acting, but the story is somewhat plain, even though that doesn't get in they way much. 4.5/5.

Well here we are, the big Oscar winner, the talk of the town, so it seems. My brother stuck this on the Bluray the other night when I was at my folks, so without any warning I was thrown into orbit alongside the ever annoying Bullock and Hollywood lapdog Clooney. One thing was for sure, it was gonna be pretty.

The lowdown, a small team of astronauts are fixing the Hubble telescope when a field of lethal debris from a recent Russian missile strike on a satellite, hits them head on. The debris causes massive damage and strands our plucky heroes in orbit with virtually nowhere to go. From here on they must fight to survive by spacewalking to other nearby space stations to try and reach any remaining capsules so they can get back down to Earth.

OK so the first thing anyone with a brain will notice is the special effects, the visuals in general. Without trying to sound too deflating I have come to expect flashy super-duper effects from most modern films these days, its a given really isn't it, if the film doesn't look ultra amazing you'd be shocked. So while this film does have the perfect realistic look of a real NASA film from a real space mission...it somehow isn't overly mind blowing truth be told. It sure does look spot on for total scientific accuracy in every aspect from the space suits, the spacecraft, the space stations, cockpit controls, weightlessness, every little nut bolt and screw, and space physics in general.

So I can understand why this film won visual effects, kudos. But then we have the plot issues and accuracy issues, yeah yeah I know but come on, a big realistic film like this had better get its facts right...yes?, no. First off this Russian missile strike on a defunct satellite?? what the splodge was that about?!. Why would a country fire a missile at a defunct satellite firstly, surely this is bound to cause a chain reaction of problems. Secondly why blow up a satellite that no longer works? seems a bit over the top to me, surely you'd bring on international outrage doing this? causing a massive disaster in space, it just seems a really dumb decision. Then you have the fact that the astronauts lose contact with control completely, really? out of all the kit they have up there on various international platforms they still can't contact control! that's scary right there.

I won't go on about the technical issues as its nitpicking really...oh just one more. The astronauts travel between the Hubble, the ISS and the Chinese space station as if they are all in the same orbit!!. I'm afraid these objects are not in the same orbit and travelling between them would take some planning and a heck of a lot of fuel and oxygen, but hey kudos for trying anyway.

Whilst watching this visual extravaganza I realised something midway through, this film is nothing more than a pumped up Universal Studios or Disney's Hollywood Studios ride (formally MGM). Its all about the visuals and the ride, the plot is minimal and the acting was pretty standard in my opinion. Of course this being shown mainly in 3D only emphasises this notion, this whole experience is merely a theme park ride, hell I'm damn sure this film will be made into a theme park ride seeing as its pretty much there anyway, I can see it now, rumbling seats and smoke. There's nothing wrong with this essentially as it does what its suppose to do and thrill you with flashy CGI, but overall I kinda felt a bit tricked or cheated as it in no way feels like an actual movie.

As I already said the acting didn't inspire me much frankly. I dislike Bullock and have never rated her as an actress in any of her films mainly because she's the same in everything with that annoying squeaky clean voice and image. The same can be said for Clooney who simply plays Clooney in EVERYTHING!!, this guy cannot act one iota, he just does his smooth smug ladies man act because that's all he can do. He acts no better in this film than he does in a recent British coffee advert, its the same performance people!!! only difference here is he has an astronauts suit on sheesh!!. 

I won't deny I didn't enjoy the film to a degree, it was nail biting at times which was all made possible down to the stupendous effects. But was it really that exciting? really? I mean the whole thing was so predictable, you know from the start the female will survive because in every film women are now the heroes (see what you have started Mr Cameron, with your 'Ripley' character). There was never a point where I didn't think she wouldn't survive otherwise there would be no film, there was only one slight surprise character wise, and I highlight *slight*.

I can see why this film made a splash and I fully backup the effects award even though in this day and age its not exactly a game changer, I think. The way they went about creating a fully realistic thriller in space that looks no different to something you'd expect to see from real footage is admirable, but that's all it is. Where as 'Apollo 13' was a nail biting epic drama, this really does feel like a short bombastic theme park ride with a wafer thin plot that's no better than a videogame. There's been a lot of fuss over this film and apart from the visuals I really don't get why. I feel like I'm repeating myself (I am) but bottom line its a big thumbs up for the effects and realism, but that's as far as it goes for me, my score reflects those two elements only.

This movie deserves 2 stars PURELY for the visual effects, everything else about this movie was pure garbage. I rarely ever write reviews on bad movies, but this one deserves to be knocked down a bit.
[Spoilers]
Oh yeah, also forget some of the huge plot holes in this movie such as: Bullock's oxygen tank dropped from about (I don't know the EXACT numbers, but these are pretty darn close) 20% to 8-10% in 5 minutes when the debris first hit the astronauts and sent her flying. Then, an hour trip with George tugging her with a jet pack and she still manages to have enough left to spend an additional 5-10 minutes struggling with George to grab onto the space station and manage her way to the entryway (oh yeah, let's have her narrowly make it as she's breathing CO2 in only the last minute or two).
Or, an additional plot hole being that she fumbles her way from space station to space station and narrowly fumbles her way back to earth. She's an astronaut who should have had a ton of training, instead she's portrayed as though she was taken straight out of highschool, given a 30 minute introduction on being in space and then sent into space for a repair mission. Oh yeah, and Clooney was acting like a kid at recess in the very beginning as he wastes his jet pack to fly around goofing off and only doing some slight work on the satellite. He gets a jet pack, but the other two don't...and he's playing with it like a kid. Then, he comes back as a vision and gives Bullock crucial information...information she should have already known as an astronaut, but let's take away all of her training and have her do "eeny-meeny-miney-mo" on a control panel.

On cinematographic terms, Gravity is absolutely, phenomenally, and without a doubt, pure perfection. The moving soundtrack flows indiscreetly with its masterful cinematography. The only drawback, however, is the plot. There is none. Period. Gravity's blank as a brick characters and a mediocre script may seem like a huge turn-off for most, however these assumptions can be washed aside as you marvel at the perfect camera-work, the sound-mixing, and the soundtrack blending together, as one, to create a suspenseful feeling that you are, indeed, drifting away, all alone, in space. 

All in all, all I can sum up about Gravity is that it's different. Should you watch it? Yes. Do you need high expectations? Er-... no. Just shut your brain off for 90 minutes and get lost in the endless, empty void of space in "Gravity."

The plot--Gravity is simply a remake of Sandra Bullock's earlier movie, "Speed" only set in space and without Keanu Reeves.  She gets into a doomed vehicle and then survives one unlikely catastrophe after another.  Since she is the only living person in most of this version, tricky things like witty dialogue don't need to be encountered.  No need for character development.

Character development--limited to a non sequitur (about 2 paragraphs long) where she suddenly divulges that she had a daughter who died,  Losing the girl evidently meant something to her but the fact that having the girl must have meant there was another human being who got close to her seems not to register.  More character background would take acting.

Acting--The best thing about this movie is that Sandra Bullock doesn't have to act.  All she has to do is climb the exterior of disabled space stations and get tossed around by space debris.

Space debris--Webster's defines it as a movie called Gravity.

Gravity (2013) - 9

"Gravity" is a reference work on the technical aspect gifted with appreciable cinematic sensibility of Alfonso Cuar√≥n. As good as the best pure entertainment in cinema nowadays, it's a simple movie easily enjoyable for the sheer sensorial experience, but with good conceptual nuance and wittiness. An engaging, frenetic and thrilling dance in the tremendous abyss of space filled with metaphors and symbolisms for Life (which anyone takes seriously/interprets as judged). Very good acting from Sandra Bullock, I enjoyed the character development of Ryan, some melodramatic moments seemed superfluous to me and distracted. I watched in 2D and still felt immersed in the adventure and assimilated the premisses. I have some doubts about the replay value, after the first view I didn't feel the impetus to re-watch, "Gravity" entertains while it lasts and it's very clear... maybe too clear, it lacks the mysterious or transcendental factor to addict me, probably it's markedly popular and accessible nature limits it in my eyes... In any case, I think "Gravity" will become a classic of contemporary cinema because it's a hallmark of technical mastery and it's "... one hell of a ride" like nothing else.

Based on the acclaim I'd heard from this film and the anticipation I had going into it, I was honestly surprised with how overrated I found the whole affair. I'll admit that without out a doubt its visual style at points is incredible (even revolutionary), but mostly I felt that everything in the movie was just overpowered or undermined by the visuals and everything else just felt disconnected and distant. I felt that the director could have changed the stylistic approach at times (some scene's would have worked better without music) and the script felt dry and at times a little too cheesy and preachy for it's own good. Even the visuals which I thought were incredible were not always consistent ; The CGI when Bullock's character was inside of the Space Station ended up looking really fake and distracting when merged with live action footage. Along with that I just felt that besides the visuals, nothing else in the film really stood by it's own merits. The thrills weren't as thrilling and they could have been, the drama wasn't as affecting, the moments that try to be profound come across and cheesy and/or overdone, and I felt like the good moments were too quickly rushed to leave a lasting impression. Overall, it wasn't as good  2013's other survival film, "All is Lost" or  director Alfonso Cuaron's earlier film, Children of Men".

Well I put off seeing Gravity and in retrospect that was a mistake.  My reasoning was that no matter how well produced it might it be it would suffer from the curse of the binary plot.  One person is going to live or die and knowing that tends to leak the drama out of the whole movie.  
Somehow that doesn't happen here, things go bad and you are never given a chance to sit back and contemplate.  The events in the film play out in a matter of a few hours in real-time and are squeezed into a 90 minute film. You get only a faint suggestion of backstory and other than Clooney being a little too self assured and charismatic, the dialogue and situations never feel forced or cheesy. 
This is a damn good film that twists the tension knife better than any movie since James Camerons Aliens. I regret not seeing it on the big screen in 3D, but it is no less powerful at home.

I can only bring myself to give Gravity 3 stars (in my defense, it's a *solid* three stars). I love space travel and I think they did an excellent job conveying a lot of things about space (and surprisingly accurately for a Hollywood film). However, the entire movie felt like it was just yelling at and pleading with me to connect with Sandra Bullock's character.

"Look how human she is," the movie kept telling me. "Don't you want to root for her to make it through this? Oh and look! She's grown as a character, even more reason for you to like her!"

The incredibly blatant way that it was shoving this down my throat was way too obvious and kind of annoying for me; honestly, it probably did more to detach me from my movie-watching experience than anything. If I'm conscious of the fact that I'm watching a movie, and one that is desperately trying to make me like its main character at that, it's going to be very hard for me to get into the experience.

If you find space and space travel at all interesting, watch this. It's pretty cool to see how they simulated weightlessness (and incredibly well, at that) and watching the ISS get torn apart in silence was terrifying and awe-inspiring at the same time. I do not entirely understand the 97% rating it has on here, but it was mildly entertaining, at least.

It was okay, nothing special.  I don't understand why the critics rave about this movie.  George Clooney  was his usual insufferable, soooo confidant self, Sandra Bullock was good, the effects were excellent.  But truly a 97%??? not worthy of it.

One-woman show. Sandra Bullock has done a great job! To be honest, I sort of fell asleep during the first half because it was like one (or two) person(s) drifting in the space trying to fix things, but then getting threatened by debris. However, when it was only Ryan (Bullock) and Matt (Clooney) that survived and they got to speak for a little bit. Well, Matt asked Ryan about her life, trying to distract her from breathing too fast (in case she wouldn't have much oxygen). However, Matt had to let go or they'd both be dead. It was then a real solo for Ryan. Just when she was about to give up living (ah-ha, how brilliant it'd be to die in the space, with silence and such lovely views to keep you company), she dreamt of Matt who came back to give her a hand (thanks to him). Then, her gathered herself together and finally made it back to the Earth. It was actually a very strikingly touching moment when she landed on the ocean, especially when she swam to the sea shore. It felt like she was reborn! Overall, it's rather good.

Gravity isn't a very complicated film, but it doesn't have to be. It's brief, it's tense, and its surprisingly emotional. Its visual effects and cinematography alone make it worth seeing. But on top of that, the sound design is fantastic (everything out in space is heard as dull reverberations - as though we're also in a space suit). And, of course, it features a great performance by Sandra Bullock , who leads most of the film as a one-person show.

Gravity is a British-American space thriller. It's a movie directed, written, produced and edited by Alfonso Curaron in 2014. The film stars Sandra Bullock,  who embodies Dr. Ryan Stone and George Clooney who embodies Matt Kowalski. They are the two main characters.
The film tells a story about three space-mans who have a mission in space. The film is about the life in the space, and the distress of someone caught in a trap in this universe. The plot was too predictable for me, and not very gripping. Personally, I guessed the end from the beginning¬†! Whereas, the spacial effects are stunning. The team did a very good job. Photography is really incredible.
Overall, it's for me, a performance wooden. I not really enjoy this movie because of the plot who not was very gripping, and I haven't hooked. All the same, the script thought-provoking. I recommend this film to anyone who loves quiet movies and movies that don't move too much.

Intense, visually stunning, well acted, and smoothly directed. Gravity is a great achievement for director Alfonso Cuaron. I absolutely loved this movie. It follows Ryan Stone, played by Sandra Bullock, and Matt Kowalski, played by George Clooney. Ryan is an engineer who is repairing this satellite in space, Kowalski is an Astronaut who is on his last mission to take Ryan to space. And from that point everything goes wrong. I'm not going to spoil too much, but stuff happens that gets the two main characters into a bit of a pickle. The movie is one of the most visually stunning movies I have seen since Avatar. It took four years to make, and they have succeeded in making one of the most gorgeous movies I have ever seen. Best use of 3D that has been put on screen. The acting in the movie is great. I really cared for the two main characters. I wanted them to get back to earth. A lot of people have a problem with the movie that it's just like a Universal Studios ride, maybe it is, I agree with them that it's like a Universal Studios ride but that's part of the reason that makes Gravity do great. Another complaint is that there isn't enough story in Gravity, that there is no back story. Who cares? Is being stuck in space not intriguing enough?   I had no real complains to the movie. I was engaged throughout the movie. It was intense; it was pumped with adrenaline for the full 90 minutes. A couple of problems are that the dialogue isn't so great, but that's how I would talk in real life. Another thing is that there is this scene that is like a dream sequence that tells the main character what to do, which kind of bothered me, it seems like an easy fix to the situation. But other than that I have no big complains to this masterpiece.

Don't waste your time trying to watch this flick unless you have great surround sound and 3d!....a pulse pounding thrill ride it is.....but a 2d no surround sound screening might feel lame and boring....best 3d movie I've seen yet!!!

Yes the cinematography was excellent but the story was lacking. Don't usually like going to the movies to get jerked around...poorly written suspense (unlikely circumstances), but alas, it was the husband's turn to pick...

"TWO ASTRONAUTS DRIFTING IN SPACE"  

- 'Gravity' is a 2013 sci-fi thriller drama by Alfonso Cuar√≥n (Children of Men, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban), starring Sandra Bullock (Speed, Crash) and George Clooney (Ocean's Eleven, From Dusk Till Dawn). Winning eight Academy Awards, due to the perfect amount of visual effects and cinematography. The movie was shown in 3D, to give it that extra dimensional twist. I must confess I really sat on the edge of my seat. With the voice of Ed Harris (The Abyss, Enemy at the Gates) as Mission Control. 'Gravity' hits the spot and is definitely a film I would recommend on seeing. Hold on tight, you're in for one hell of a ride... 

Doing some service on the Hubble Space Telescope on Explorer, medical engineer Dr. Ryan Stone (Bullock) is accompanied by veteran astronaut Matt Kowalski (Clooney), as Mission Control in Houston (Harris) warns them a cloud of debris caused by a explosion on a Russian Satellite. The debris' impact catapults Stone into space, where she loses all contact with Mission Control. Luckily she is found by Kowalski, who is wearing a thruster pack. Together they make their way back to a destroyed Explorer. All the other astronauts are dead. All contact with Earth has been broken. While Stone's oxygen is running low, the two survivors try to reach the International Space Station. Can they make their way back to Earth or will they drift into the endless universe?

Well, proof again the the general American public is easily entertained and lack actual real world knowledge of how basic physics works.  Nothing was remotely believable, even in movie form, and this I had zero tension nor a care that the main character (who by her own admission) had zero qualification as an astronaut, was not going to survive. Oh my god.

Sandra Bullock was either a bad choice for an actor or the story should of at least had a competent astronaut. There were points in the movie I just wanted to call her an idiot - yes she has had a terrible past and it's her first real space mission but damn...how did she even pass the tests to go into space? Clooney was amazing and it just doesn't make sense why the story lets Sandra be the hero.

Space - endless void with undiscovered mystery things that we probably would never know. There is nothing to carry sound. No air pressure. No oxygen. Weightlessness, dead silence, extreme temperature fluctuations, loneliness, emptiness and darkness... Now, imagine you there, your body is levitating. Peace and quiet, you close your eyes, think about your life... and BOOM, know you are rotating  and quickly  going to outer space. And you released that there is no help for you and you are simply waiting for the end of your Life Journey.

That nightmare happened to Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock), medical engineer who has never been in space before. She was accompanied by Matt Kowalski(George Clooney), veteran astronaut making his final mission. It was supposed to be casual repair of space ship. Unfortunately they flew in meteor shower and smash their ship to small pieces and both Dr. Ryan and Matt gone in space void. Special effects and music ware really great and perfectly selected to this part. They highlighted the drama of the scene and showed powerless in their eyes. It was very touching.

Whole story has been told in a very good way. They give as a chance to meet the characters, to feel the connection, to personify with them. If we care about someone, it is hard to lose him. It very hard to achieve when viewer sits in front of the screen with big eyes and can wait what happen next - and  they did it.

So, if you would like to see dramatic movie with great special effects then your time in the cinema won't be wasted. If you also like little funny accents in this kind of films this film has been made for you.

SPOILER 


About 10 or 15 minutes into the movie, there is "dramatic" scene that is critical to all that might follow.


The scene is so laughable, that I quit watching the movie at that point.


The Bullock character is attached to the space station by a rope wrapped around her foot.

She is a short ways "below" the station.


Clooney's character is about 5 feet "below" Bullock's character (5 feet closer to Earth). There is a rope between them.


In the scene, Bullock has to let Clooney go, because, apparently he's too "heavy" to pull in.


This scene should embarrass any high-school graduating a student who could take it seriously.


The station, Bullock, and Clooney are all in free fall (around the Earth).


Clooney is the tiniest bit closer to the center of the Earth than is Bullock (about 5 feet closer). The real problem Bullock would have faced would be to not pull too hard. She needed to give the rope attached to Clooney, a single tiny pull.

Clooney would have then gained momentum which would have carried him past Bullock, towards the station.

In fact, just holding onto the rope, it would have been difficult to avoid pulling him.

"Either way, it'll be one hell of a ride," Sandra Bullock shudders before taking a deep breath, one she knows could be her last, as she braces herself for one of the most intense and iconic scenes in Gravity. Indeed, Gravity is one hell of a ride, and yet it so much more than simply a ride. Gravity is a transcendental experience in cinema that is unlike anything we have seen before or are likely to see again anytime soon. It is breathtaking in every sense of the word, from its stunning portrayal of zero gravity in space to brutally heart-pounding sequences. As the film becomes layered with deeply existential questions concerning life, loss, and survival, Gravity becomes as consuming as its most thrilling scenes.

Gravity opens with a silently breathtaking shot of Earth from space, as if we are slowly orbiting it from afar. The scene subtly gravitates toward the Hubble telescope, where we meet astronauts Ryan Stone and Matt Kowalski, played by Sandra Bullock and George Clooney. They are on a repair mission on the telescope before being notified by NASA that the Russians have launched a missile at one of their own satellites. This anti-satellite test, however, has resulted in a massive amount of space debris that causes catastrophic damage to numerous satellites in the surrounding area. It is not long before Stone and Kowalski are told to abort the mission-the debris is rapidly heading straight toward them. Due to the velocity of the debris, they are unable to return to their shuttle before the maelstrom begins. In a scene that is equally beautiful and terrifying, the two astronauts fight for their lives in a shower of catastrophic destruction and silent explosions. After all, there is no sound in space.

The artistry of Gravity lies not only in large-scale shots of the vast universe and shattered space stations but in its detail as well, such as the subtle reflection of Earth's oceans on an astronaut's helmet or a small screw as it slowly gravitates off-screen. Director Alfonso Cuar√≥n provides a wholly unprecedented experience in Gravity, staying true to the scientific principles of space such as lack of sound and the surreal effects of zero gravity. Real astronauts, such as Buzz Aldrin and Michael J. Massimino, have acclaimed the film's realism, comparing it to their own experiences in space. Gravity is a film where the whole is truly greater than the sum of its parts, because when every detailed piece of the plot comes together, it creates a flawlessly phenomenal cinematic experience unlike any other. Gravity gleams in a year full of brainless, eye-candy films lacking substance, and it is too extraordinary to be missed.

So far the film that won me over! A cinematic TRIUMPH, PHENOMENAL, FANTASTIC! A masterpiece of cinema so bravo to the cast and crew of Gravity. Alfonso Cuaron co-wrote and directed this heart-pounding thriller where the 1.5 hours flew by film aficionados. I concur with Liam Lacey of Globe and Mail who wrote: ""Gravity, a weightless ballet and a cold-sweat nightmare, intimates mystery and profundity, with that mixture of beauty and terror that the Romantics called the sublime." Exactly! Sandra Bullock steals the show as Dr. Ryan Stone, a medical engineer on her first shuttle mission and George Clooney is a veteran astronaut named Matt Kowalsky. During a spacewalk to fix a communications data port, tragedy strikes in the way of debris going so fast that can destroy anything on its path..The film continues from that point and I assure you that there is never a dull moment because there is constant action. I liked the fact that the story touches on spiritual themes and I will say this: even in space we have angels looking out for us, signs that we cannot ignore. It is up to us whether we continue the journey and fight for survival or giving up. GRAVITY IS ONE OF THE BEST SCIENCE FICTION FILMS IN YEARS AND it felt so real, so vivid. After watching this gem, you will feel apprehensive about our attempt to conquer outer space because the human race is so small, fragile, and incomparable to the harsh environment of outer space and its vastness. Two thumbs way up for this seven Oscar winner and HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

The great Homer Simpson once exclaimed, "Stupid Gravity!"  That emotional outburst weighs (pun intended) upon every moment of Alfonso Cuaron's space thriller Gravity.  It is a film about the forces that control us set in an environment where we no longer have control and even our most high-tech equipment keeps us only nanometers or nanoseconds away from total annihilation.  

Gravity represents Cuaron's long-awaited re-entry (again, pun intended) into the cinematic arena.  His last film was dystopian masterpiece Children of Men.  Gravity does not quite reach the heights of Children of Men, but it is certainly a beautiful, masterfully directed, emotional, and suspenseful thrill ride. 

The film is eye candy at its absolute best, but Cuaron also frames shots and directs his actors with perfectly artistic touches.  Still, the film runs the risk of being all surface and no depth.  Fortunately, Cuaron turns into a kind of existential fable about a woman trying to find meaning and purpose again in a world whose absurd cruelty had rendered her life vacant and pointless.  Her quest for survival in the harshest of conditions becomes a tale about the human will to live and the need to ascribe meaning and value to existence-it is a Sartrean quest for essence in the face of the crushingly absurd face of pure, absolute existence.  

Cuaron almost perfectly achieves his purpose, but the moves are a little bit too predictable for the film to be completely effective and original.  Still, Gravity is an amazing and intelligent experience from a truly accomplished master of the cinema.

Gravity was the most intense and anxiety-inducing movie I have ever been to. Director Alfonso Cuaron deserved the Oscar he received for creating not just a film, but an experience. He put the camera literally inside the helmets of the astronauts, making us feel what they felt. The event does not let up for one moment, making the audience feel constantly on edge.

The film's theme is intriguing to me, especially its Biblical applications. You don't really know what you'd do or Who you'd turn to in that kind of life-or-death situation. It's an illustration of the war adage that there are no atheists in foxholes. In times of sheer survival and insurmountable odds, most people hope for and look to something bigger than themselves to rescue them.

It's  as if we were all designed to have such hope...

I don't understand all the hype and the kudos this movie gets OTHER than for its special effects .. sort of.  I personally feel there have been special effects at least on the surface more dazzling or at least equal to what is contained in the movie.  But not being an expert I cannot state conclusively that this movie is not groundbreaking in that area.  But the acting?  Basically, Sandra Bullock has learned several different ways to breathe heavy.  She delivers her lines no more brilliantly than she has in any other movie she has appeared in.  And well .. she did not get the Oscar.  The plot?  To me it is a stretch to believe that in the short time she had to train that she would be able to accomplish what she did in the American designed vehicle let alone any foreign made one.  The basic story line .. danger and/or possible death due to not being able to return to the safety of earth from space .. done before and far more effectively in say Apollo 13.  It just boggled my mind that this movie attained such critical success.  I found it boring and disappointing.

But as a a feature film to me there just isn't enough story to fill the 2 hours. After the first hour was through I was ready for it to end, and my girlfriend was asleep. Sandra Bullock's character probably should have chosen another profession because she destroys everything she touches.
