OK. I have just witnessed this film and can't believe that everyone is fawning over this piece of crap. I know, I will explain. First the good thing, and I say thing because there was literally only one thing that was good.The effects were cool. (But seriously, no better than the most recent Call of Duty video game! I swear)  And then there's the rest. Firstly, it seems to me that they said "Hey let's make a film with 2 actors in it and another 2 who will just be disembodied voices. When it's over we'll have made $300 million dollars and only have to pay 3 people" I am going to be picky here as I have always had a fascination with the space program and science in general. This film was in short, ridiculous. None of this shit could have happened in reality. Well, most of it anyway. As far as acting goes, it was horrible as well. George Clooney was in it for about 3 minutes. Not including the brief moronic dream sequence where he comes back in and makes some remarks about vodka. Really for all who don't know it, if you open a pressurized door like that, you'd be frozen solid and dead immediately, that's how I knew it was a dream and Clooney really wasn't there (I know I'm a observational genius!)

       The rest of the time is spent watching Sandra Bullock float around in her underwear with an apparently endless supply of oxygen. Emotionally lacking as well "I had a daughter, she fell and hit her head, and that was it"  Well, she really was plumbing the depths of human emotion there. You'll wish you hit your head and went to sleep for rest of this film too. She then proceeds to jump into different space craft as if they were Toyota Corollas and she had the keys to all of them, she apparently speaks fluent Russian and Chinese or at least enough to fly all of their spacecraft effectively. Not bad for a Medical engineer? Oh yeah, that's right this is her first mission and she already knows everything about everything. Even more ridiculous was how she ship jumps and each time barely catches the handle (How thrilling.) as if there would be a film if she missed. And on to the final 2 bits of foolishness. 1. She actually used a fire extinguisher to fly around using the exhaust to function as her directional control. 2. She just jumps into the final craft to re-enter and all the conditions for re-entry are perfect. and she lands on a nice sandy beach, the end. Oh, and her quotes are fucking idiotic BTW, "Either way it'll be one hell of a ride". Really...? In the running for the best film of the year. I don't think so. More proof that these awards are fixed as they always have been. What a waste of time.

The beauty of our universe is infinite and we may seem to be insignificant in comparison, but the reality is each and every life is precious.  Lifes value is within our own self worth and our inner desire to survive. This movie would be great in recovery centers and classrooms for childen that struggle with the meaning of life. People ponder over what their value is, specially in this massive world filled with so many people walking a long side of one another. We often feel lost and a lone in this crowed little blue marble we call earth. We are not a lone, yet we live only in our own skin, with our own thoughts, and our own power to choose how to live and how we want to survive each and every day. Tethered along within the deep storytelling like a backseat driver, the viewer will find themselves massively suspended during the breathtaking action sequences.  Gravity is a classic example of Joseph Campbell's a Hero's Journey with Ryan as our hero. Ryan's adventure into outer space reveals the reasons why cataclysm in life may be overcome regardless on how riddled with pain one may seem.  Gravity revolves around the truth and meaning of human life and how we search for so many metaphorical vehicles to find confidence and overall, happiness and stability.

Phenomenal, I can't compare this film to any other as it's simply unlike anything out there. Even James Cameron himself called it "the best space movie ever done", big words from the man who helmed Avatar and Aliens. Gravity is this: Seasoned Astronaut Matt Kowalsky and new engineer Ryan Stone are repairing the Hubble space satellite when out of nowhere they are hit by space debris, knocking them off comms and into space without any tethers, floating away into the further. Their mission now is to get back to Earth. This set-up simply expands as the stakes get higher, Alfonso Cuar√≥n is the new master of suspense and lump in your throat storytelling. Faultless writing, undeniably perfect visuals and a big sense of wonder all shot in 3D, one of the most fitting and finest uses of the technology, putting you on edge permanently. Let me tell you this now, the International Space Station sequence will absolute terrify, grip and shock you. Sandra Bullock is amazing, I cannot fault her, the sound of her panting in terror and the scenes where she reflects on her life and her uncertain future are the anchor for this movie, plus George Clooney's humour keeps you grounded amongst all the chaos. Steven Price's soundtrack is frantic and powerful enough to spin your head, echoing back to M83's beautiful score in Oblivion. Would I watch it again? Dumb question, this movie is watchable so many times and most definitely deserving of all it's Oscars. What will Cuar√≥n do next, that is the question?

Within the first five minute of this movie I knew it was going to be good. The reason being is that the movie stayed on one shot for a good five minutes and it made no cuts or edits whatsoever. And you know what? It didn't need any. Because the master shot was so good that it didn't need to cut to any other shots. Gravity is a very intense and engaging movie from beginning to end although the engagement is due more to the fantastic special effects and camera work rather than the actual story or characters and to tell you the truth neither of those aspects were very interesting. Or at least the story wasn't. This is not a bad thing though. In fact that is far from being a bad thing for this movie. Besides the movie couldn't have been done without the special effects. But it wasn't just the special effects either it was the camera work that worked perfectly in tandem with those special effects and it just gave me the feeling that I was floating in space alongside Ryan. Now lets move onto the thing I mentioned earlier: the story and characters. While those components of the movie weren't given the best of details, they were given enough detail that I was able to stay engaged with the characters and I cared about them enough to root for them because they were at least given some sort depth to their characters. And in the end I was glad that the girl survived her long journey through space. Give this movie a go. It's worth it. Trust me.

The Best fil of the year no matter what people say. In my case, I had to watch it several times to fully uncover the whole second layer of the movie: what Alfonso Cuaron really wanted to tell. This is the story of a very depressed woman, who feels as if she is just drifting into a scary void (in the film: the space), and she can't find a reason to go on. Obstacles (debris) keep coming into her life and hitting her, and breaking everything around her. At some point, she finds the strength to keep fighting, and she learns a very important lesson: √É¬¢√Ç√ÇThe way I see it, there's only two possible outcomes. Either I make it and have one hell of a story to tell, or I burn up in the next ten minutes. Either way, whichever way. No harm no foul. Because either way, it will be one hell of a ride!√É¬¢√Ç√Ç? And she ends it with √É¬¢√Ç√ÇI'm ready√É¬¢√Ç√Ç?. So, yes, this to me is a very inspiring story about enjoying the ride of life no matter how hard it gets. In the end, there's only one life and it's ONE HELL OF A RIDE!

There's something awfully beautiful about√Ç¬†Gravity, and I'm not just speaking of the acclaimed special effects. But the whole of√Ç¬†Gravity√Ç¬†is beautiful in it's examination of life, and subsequently death. The cast of two involves the talent of Sandra Bullock (Ryan) and George Clooney (Matt). Ryan is overly motivated to maintain life (with a tragic death in her family); Matt is much more relaxed, and looks at life on a macro level. While both of their figurative homes are in space, one is more willing to stay there than the other. The film is intense, but I wasn't caught up in the technical, so for myself the drama aspect was where more of my admiration comes from. The birth/life/death symbolism in√Ç¬†Gravity√Ç¬†is great. While all the technical aspects interested me I'd give special props to director of photography Lubezki, who has previously impressed me with√Ç¬†Tree of Life√Ç¬†andChildren of Men. While this isn't my absolute favorite of 2013, I believe it'll be the most remembered.√Ç¬†

For anyone who gives this movie anything more than three stars, I suggest watching it on your home television without 3D. I rented this film expecting something amazing because I love space films, it had good reviews, and respectable actors. The reality is that it took a lot to contain my laughter. There is absolutely no plot or character development, so I felt no connection with the characters. The glossed over backstory of Ryan was not enough to make me feel anything for her. I need more than one sentence to do that. The dialogue was only a means to fill in the spaces between the numerous action sequences that are very hard to believe. When you make a movie or write a book about something that actually happens every day such as astronauts in space, then there should be a shred of reality to make it believable (even in fiction) and this movie doesn't have it. I know it is apparently supposed to be about someone trying to find a reason to live, but I've seen better. Ryan is probably the dumbest character I have ever seen in a movie. A lot of the problems she faces are her own doing which added to my annoyance. I'm sure on a big IMAX 3d screen this movie was epic because of the visuals, but it has nothing going for it on the small screen. Watch it if you are supremely bored. Otherwise, you can watch Armageddon, Sunshine, Mission to Mars, or Space Cowboys and actually be entertained on a more intelligent level and by intelligent I mean there is more to the films than just lights, camera, action.

Arguably the best tagline for a movie EVER, "In space no one can hear you scream" Alien's "In space no one can hear you scream" tagline is arguably the best tagline for a movie of all-time. That same tagline could easily be effectively utilized for Alfonso Cuar√≥n's latest thriller, Gravity.

Starring two unknowns by the names of George Clooney and Sandra Bullock, Gravity puts the two A-listers together as a medical engineer and an astronaut that must work in tandem to survive once a freak accident leaves them adrift in space.

Their struggle takes place after debris from a Russian satellite comes speeding through their orbit ripping their space shuttle to shreds causing Dr. Ryan Stone (Bullock) to float untethered in space. Coming to her aid is astronaut Matt Kowalsky (Clooney) who estimates that the debris will again circle the earth and again zip past their location in approximately 90-minutes. Their mission quickly changes into a race to survival 600km above the earth where help from anyone outside of each other is impossible.

Alfonso Cuar√≥n is chiselling himself quite a career. He was last behind the camera for Children of Men (2006) which was nominated for three Academy Awards and he was also responsible for the best film in the Harry Potter film series with Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004). But Gravity is his best work to date.

Bullock carries the film (expect some murmurs for a Best Actress nomination) and Gravity centers on the two main characters only. There are no other developed characters. Two other astronauts and a radio voice from Houston, Texas are the only other character influences and their parts wouldn't amount to 2 minutes if strung in order.

With only two actors to carry the entire 90-minute runtime, the movie relies heavily on its visuals of space and the various orbiting stations with the earth always prominent in the background. And the visuals are fantastic. There are no side-stories, sub-plots, unnecessary fluff or sexual tension between the characters. Just a desperate attempt to make the most of the oxygen they have left.

Gravity is the best 3D film ever. Ever. Add to the mix the incredible visuals and perfect sound (both loud and quiet) and you have a faultless mix. Gravity will contend for Oscar's in Visual Effects, Sound and Editing.

Cuar√≥n incredibly is able to give his audience a sense of claustrophobia whether his cast are inside an orbiting capsule or in the vast darkness of space. And as the astronauts deal with each new developing tragedy, the audience will themselves be gasping for air rooting for the character's success in each new attempt at survival.

With still a few months left in the year, it's too early to call a film the year's best. But Gravity will definitely be there on many lists at the year's conclusion. It's that breathtaking. It's that good.

Rating: 8/10

One such as me can't help but feel a great deal of excitement and anticipation when I see a film get critical reviews rating it in the 9 or above category and also see it receive 7 Oscars.  Oh, and that level of eagerness is only ratcheted up to 11 when said film is directed by the genius behind Children of Men, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, and Y Tu Mama Tambien.  I admit that going into my first viewing of this film, I had extremely high expectations.

Ultimately, Gravity is a good film.  And I mean that in the most disappointed sense of the word.

My high expectations proved to be far too high.  As high as the space this film is set within.  Alas, the movie doesn't reach such heights, and it really is a shame because it certainly looks like a film that is doing just that.  

Visually speaking, Gravity is one of the most spectacular films I've ever seen.  The special effects are among the very best in film history.  No sci-fi film has ever made the awe, wonder, and horror of outer space come to life the way Gravity manages to.  It is a visual feast for the eyes and one of the very few films that is required viewing in 3D.  And that is where Gravity's greatness begins and ends, which is why the rest of it is so disappointing.

Much like its contemporary, Avatar, Gravity is an amazing looking film that has very little depth to it.  There are times where it feigns depth, still like Avatar, but with very little digging one finds little to chew on.  Yes, the horror and drama and action are engrossing and thankfully the film doesn't drag on and on, but it would've been nice to have something to talk about other than the film's special effects once the credits roll.  

Even the performances aren't particularly noteworthy.  Yes, Sandra Bullock was nominated for Best Actress for this film, but I just don't see why.  She isn't bad at all.  She does her job well and believably, but nothing at all stands out about her role.  Clooney actually sticks out more in this film, and he's in it far less than Bullock.  However, he doesn't really stick out for good reasons.  In fact, one might say that Clooney's character illustrates everything wrong and disappointing about this film.  His character is the cookie-cutter veteran of his profession who spews out old cliches and stale platitudes about survival until he ultimately *SPOILER ALERT* dies to keep the newbie alive.  This is really all Gravity has to offer beyond its visuals: motivational survival speeches, "Look how beautiful the view is" cliches, and a lot of heavy breathing by Sandra Bullock.

I know, I'm harping on this movie a lot, despite giving it a good score.  It is a good movie, but dammit it could have been great!  It should have been great!  I was told it was great!  Alas, it's just good.

Review:
What a fantastic visual experience. I was wondering what the hell the director was going to do for an hour and a half with someone floating in space, but after watching the film, I'm very impressed. I can now see what people are going on about! Sandra Bullock deserves all of the praise that she is getting for her performance. It couldn't have been easy to show emotion whilst floating from all of the place. The director cleverly added an in depth storyline to Bullocks character which made the movie watchable for everyone. The main thing that is great about the movie, has to be how the movie looks and feels. It's extremely realistic and you really do feel the intensity and emotion throughout the movie. The director has definitely upped the bar in Hollywood. A Great Watch!

Round-Up:
I honestly can say that I haven't seen a movie like this before. The closest movie that I can think of was Moon which was also based on one character stuck in space, but this concentrates on Bullocks journey to earth. When the debris hit that spaceship, it really did look amazing, which made me think how great it must have look in 3D or in the cinema. Anyway, this I some of those movies that I can watch over and aver again, which is very rare for me. The only problem that I personally found with the film was the ending, but that's just me being picky.

Gravity! A Cinematic masterstroke of pure unadulterated visual effects and this sensible feeling of weightlessness. The script or dialogue doesn't have much of an attractive driving force to keep you engaged for 2 hours however the visual and the action sequences of destruction and mayhem holds your attention. It's like witnessing a beautiful train wreck as Sandra Bullock gives a gut wrenching performance just on her physical and facial expressions. George Clooney, cool, calm, collected-he acts as her coach and conscience throughout the film. He achieves this with reckless abandon but in a precisely delivered way. Now, on to the orchestra-- simply fits the action sequences like a hand in a glove --riveting but not over powering. I could say this film was slightly overrated but it was a thrill ride, a different pace, a distinctive perspective from director Alfonso Cuar√≥n. His approach and outlook on space and the element of weightlessness is so surreal that it's invitingly sickening. How can this be so real, so genuine? Some acts felt a little expansive, a little too filler-- especially when Sandra is alone at the space station. However, after I finished and reflected on the sequences, script and pace of the film-the reasons why Alfonso Cuar√≥n calculatingly  directed those painfully slow quiet monologues with Sandra alone or communicating with a foreigner via radio was completely understandable. I think this film was slightly overrated but a flat out thrill ride nonetheless. A must have in any Blu Ray collection!

*SPOILERS* 
Gravity, being hailed as a cinematic masterpiece and expected to be the "Greatest Space Movie of All Time" - James Cameron. The audience and critic response however was hugely mixed. Although yes, some agree with the Cameron, and did completely adore the new space epic, the others were massively disappointed. Unfortunately, I am one of the dissatisfied viewers. 

Having seen the trailers and being amongst the massive hype for Gravity, of course I could not wait to see the movie on the big screen. In fact, I actually planned to skip the opening weekend and visit an even bigger screen, London's IMAX. Unfortunately, (for the time) I was gutted to have missed the screening, which resulted in me watching the 2D version. Now, yes I do suggest that I would have written a slightly more positive review if I had indeed watched the film in 3D, considering the new use of technologies won it an astonishing 7 Oscars. However, I did not. And in a way I am pleased, because the experience showed me how little the overestimated film had to offer other than the visuals. 

I usually would give a film the benefit of the doubt and suggest that maybe if the enormous hysteria wasn't so enormous, then I wouldn't have had such high expectations and would therefore not be as disappointed. However, I don't believe this. Gravity lacked exciting narrative, character development and emotional involvement. Having enjoyed the Mexican director, Alfonso Cuaron's Y Tu Mama Tambien (2001) due to the deep character development and emotional manipulation, I expected more with Gravity. There was not one moment within the film that made me feel sorry or scared for Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock), which is also surprising considering I respect Bullock as an actress. Awkwardly, I did not find myself wanting Stone to get out of any situations or even returning home. Other than one underdeveloped story she reluctantly tells Matt Kowalski (George Clooney) about losing her daughter, there is no reason we would want Stone to return home. Regarding both Bullock and Clooney as remarkable actors, the film and narrative did not do either of them justice. They were boring characters with no need or desire to get home safely. 

Plot holes. There are many I could discuss but I will only mention a few. Bullock, for a lot of the screen time, is untethered, spinning and whirling around space. This is highly unlikely as NASA provide an emergency pack, which is programmed to automatically adjust, roll and pitch to stop the astronaut from spinning. It is routine that the jet pack will then be manually taken control of and used to return to the space vehicle. It is also known that there is no sound in space, which the audience is also reminded at the very start of the film. However, we hear the wrench actuating when used by Bullock in the very exposition. 

Something that really infuriated me was the resolution. What could be more dissatisfying than seeing Bullock crawl to the surface of what looks like another abandoned land. There is nobody to help her, nothing to make us feel relief or happiness that she is back on Earth. The only positive is that is actually humorous watching Bullock learn how to walk again. Other than that, the ending is nothing but another boring and frustrating scene in a movie full of them. 

I can't help but replay the moment where Bullock is barking to a Chinese man from inside her isolated space vessel. Barking. Like a Dog. I understand that Bullock is at the end of her tether and is convinced she is on her deathbed. However I do not think this is a valid enough reason. This is completely embarrassing for Bullock and the director. Alone and scared, Stone finds herself on her space radio and finds herself in contact with a man in China when trying to find help. He doesn't understand a word on English so Stone ends up finding comfort in the mans dog. Strange, I know. Bullock spends the next moments barking to the dog and to make things weirder, we then hear an uncomfortable cry from a baby. Although the majority of the films are completely predictable, this certainly was not. During this scene Bullock also curls up in the fetus-like stance and whirls round and round. This could not be more of an obvious symbolism. 

All round, Gravity was predictable and highly overrated (in my opinion of course). Cuaron and his son spent an amazing 6 years paying so much time and effect perfecting the visuals and hiring two insanely famous actors to add bankability to their movie. However during this process, they completely forgot about the attention they needed to have been paying to the plot, dialogue and characters. No wonders there are doubts about the 1969 moon landing. Disappointing.

A long time ago a made a shitty video review on Gravity so I decided to settle my thoughts once and for all with my writing.  I still stand by that it's pretty good and a must see in the theaters but I refuse to call it the Citizen Cane of space dramas.  

First off it goes without saying that Gravity created a great space environment.  The triple threat of the directing, music, and special effects would end up making such a harsh environment so believable.  Little details like having muffled or no sound in space and long continuous shots are to thank for that.  Like do you realize how insane it is to have a shot lastly for over 10 to 15 minutes in the beginning?  It's great film making by any standard and Cuaron rightly earned that Oscar.  

I wish I could give the same praise to the writing and acting but I have to be honest.  Let me start off by saying that if you're going to have minimal characters in a movie then it's reasonable to expect greater acting and character development (ex Shame).  To be blunt, Sandra Bullock doesn't live to that expectation or her character Ryan Stone.  Now I know judging a performance can be pretty subjective but keep in mind she wasn't the movies first choice or the seconds (third's time the charm?).  I find it distracting when she's not consistently shivering in a freezing station because you know, that's how our bodies work?  Kind of makes it more obvious her breath was done in post production.  Keep stuttering 'no,' that'll convey how terrified or frustrated you are.  Many claustrophobic tend to injury themselves out of frustration and you'd think that being trapped in space of all places we would see that.  Kind of think of it they also feel nauseated and hyperventilate (she does more so when she's spinning).  After all that spinning she doesn't throw up or hyperventilate (as much) when's she's trapped in a station.  It only shows, you know, her humanity which makes for better development.  Her performance wasn't bad but it wasn't great either. 

No complaints with George Clonney's performance even though he was playing George Clooney (figurative statement).  (Mid-spoiler in this section) However, there's an expectation to feel emotional for his character when he's only in the movie for a little under one third of it that I just don't care.  The movie is only 90 minutes and there's only so much you can do with that running time. 

Does anyone else not find it incredibly stupid when George Kowalsky Clooney tells Stone to stop talking to preserve Oxygen but keeps persisting that she tell her story.  Like oh no you're running low on Oxygen, but first, tell me/audience about your daughter.   Thanks for the obvious symbolism that you held the shot on for a good minute just to tell about her rebirth and innocence (kind of cool).  Thanks Stone for telling me the debris is coming, and how much time you have left, and that you see the other station.  Towards the end Stone even tells us literally and thematically her situation which would need me spoiling it.  All I'll say it has to do with that daughter story, you might now what I'm talking about if you've seen the movie already.

It got a little repetitive going to different stations twice and she would just barely grab the last bar or object.  One scene it happens twice where she barely grabs the end of her rope to just barely hang at the end of that parachute.  I would list more but I want to keep spoiler to a minimum.  You start to lose some of the suspense when you overuse that trick.   

Beyond that it's nitpicking (or me being an asshole).  I'm not going to pretend I know everything about space but call me crazy I doubt a fire hydrant will work Wall-E style.  Some of the 3D felt gimmicky, like grabbing a wrench at the audience for the second time.  Is it really appropriate to have her tear drop in 3D during an emotional scene?  Unless you're really going to argue me the artistic value of that. 

After all of that it might sound I hate it but no I still enjoyed myself a lot.  It was a theater experience I'll remember and would recommend you watch it there if you haven't.  If I ever get the chance I'll pick it up on blu-ray which is something I consider an honor.  If this was your favorite movie of 2013 I have no problem with that.  Like I said, don't pretend it's the Citizen Cane of space dramas or an excellent character study.  I didn't mean to bash it but it gets enough praise as it is.  7/10.

This movie blew me away. The visuals were absolutely spectacular, the audio was also really intense. I really felt like I was lost in the vacuum of space. To be honest, the story was a little obvious, but I don't think the point was for anyone to be really thrown off or kept guessing about the story. The ending did get me a little, but hey that's a good thing right? To all of the haters out there who thought that this didn't deserve nearly as much credit as it did at the oscars, I say watch it again. Although I could pretty much guess everything that was going to happen, the way the story was told through a variety of long takes, visual cues played through reflections, absence of audio, and many more really nicely used filmmaking techniques made it a perfectly executed way to tell the story of someone helplessly floating around in the vastness of space. The acting from Sandra Bullock was really believable as well, George Clooney's character was a little nonchalant about the whole situation, (I guess that's his character but still...) I still really enjoyed his performance. I thought that keeping Earth in the background of almost all of the shots also was a really awesome choice by the filmmakers because it really showed that they are so close to earth, but at the same time they are in a whole different world entirely. Great job, and congrats on the oscar awards.

Have you ever watched a movie in space and convinced you self that you actually watching a space? ..We see many movies in the past about space of the same style over and over again, but with this film you will see something real and absolutely new. Most the space films are always full of greeny or blueshy stupid aliens , odd form of spaceship, and frekey people swim and walking in space without speed limit. The power of Gravity is that no heroes, there are no 1,2,3 acts in the storytelling, and there are no rules flowing the 180 degree. In Gravity I see a new Sovite style of editing, the film powerfully use of 3D with completely than other films. With unquestionable great of camera movements,the the promising filmmaker Afonso Coron did his film, with  a new point-view in cinema to the space. He makes film that we never see it before in the  history of the cinema. This film offers simply the best entreatment in term of visually aspect. The film genuinely deals with CGI technology in smart way. Making film that so real with CGI is hard. Many films in the 3D cinema have bad results in term of 3D. The three-dimensional team in Gravity  difanes how to use the animation to reveals the humanity, not just to make us scream or shook.  For first time in history of the 3D cinema, the film crow use 3D models appears to your seat in about ONLY less than 5% of the total shots, that is a difficult choice.

As the great Ang Lee's (Life of Pi). and before that Martin scoresesse's (Hugo) this film is about part of a movement, I would argue, that called the  renaissance. It changes how people should think inside holwood in term of making films with 3D modles. Many people don't like the story in Gravity, some people find it silly, don't make any sense, and full of sadness. Let's talk about that for a second, with this film we been conditioned with more than 100 years of making, watching, and reading about space, and science fiction films about specific treatment; lots of actions with fast cuts in the montage, most of the films with a leading man, and procedure of filmmking that follows the rules. That is why Gravity so effective. Meticulously story in the film is not just about the lead lady, is more about human being, the way we think, cry, and love in a critical moments. Consecutively the film give us a work of art, in cinema that we should deal with it as Data new form of filmmaking. 

The montage is highly stylize with timing,the long shots that Alfonso preferred to keeps it, there for not to distract the viewer. He also maintains the tension and excitement in the action scenes. Coron keeps us know that space flight is not for tourism as CNN or BBC used to told us all the time. This Latino director lets his camera talk instead of his storytelling, he rebells in the montage as the Russians did before, breaking the rules of the shots, as in the French wive filmmakers did. Wather we like the film, or dislike, we should identify the key in this film in which; It is a different from all the past cinema in Hollywood, and invites many young people to learn more about great use of cinematic shots through the revolution of the 3D.

The film begins with a statement of a few facts and laws of physics and one lie. Mere seconds later it manages to contravene all of them, including the false one. By the time Gravity reaches its conclusion 90 minutes later, it has contradicted nearly all we know about space and the mechanisms that govern our world. The audience leaves theatres with a better understanding of what makes the universe tick. They know, for example, that in order to get from the ISS to Tiangong, all you have to do is locate it in the darkness of space, point a fire extinguisher in the opposite direction and press the handle. I'm glad that science-fiction is finally fulfilling one of its primary purposes: education.

This is definitely the most overrated movie that I have ever had to force myself to sit through. This film has been widely hailed as being scientifically accurate, when in fact it has scenes that contravene the most basic laws of physics; a characteristic that I found disturbing as it shows up how scientifically illiterate our culture really is. What bothers me about this film is not that it is fantasy, which I can enjoy, but that it is fantasy that purports to be scientific. 

I did some research and found out that the film's science adviser Kevin Grazier explained that the scene where Clooney cuts himself loose from Bullock to save her (itself a tired Hollywood cliche) was necessary because the cord she was tethered to was still absorbing their kinetic energy, which apparently was so enormous it would have caused the lines to fail and would have doomed them both had he not cut loose. Well, first of all the kinetic energy could not have been very great because they were each able to hold on to the line connecting them with one hand without apparent strain. Secondly unless the cord that Bullock had her leg entangled in was supper stretchy, like miles and  mies of stretch, (I did not see it stretch at all) the kinetic energy of the shock load would have been either absorbed or caused the line to fail almost immediately. But the two have a conversation for a full minute (I timed it) before he cuts himself loose. This is as nonsensical as jumping up in the air (in earth gravity) and hanging out up there at the deadpoint for more than a full minute before falling back down - the physics of cartoons.  As a rock climber I have taken numerous falls on a climbing rope (which does stretch) and I know that the shock load (which I could not possibly hold with one or even both hands) is dissipated quickly - probably in less than a second. I guess that next time my partner catches me in a fall though I should worry about Mr. Grazier's mysterious energy that is going to keep pulling on me and break the rope. 

The movie is full of ridiculous scenes like this, which could not possibly happen except in some alternate universe with completely different laws of physics. This film is much closer to Plan Nine from Outer Space than masterpieces like 2001 and Apollo 13. Ed Wood, I'm sure, would have loved it.
over rated not worth the money

I remember seeing the trailer for this about a year ago, and just judging from that a couple things stuck out to me. 
1.  Sandra Bullock's constant panting and screaming drove me mad. 
2.  When the astronauts bounced around it looked really funny.  
Now that I've seen the actual film in full, those two things turned out to be completely accurate.  

Lets just dive in.  Gravity's biggest positive is also its biggest negative; the CGI and visuals.  This film has been praised beyond belief for its visual effects, and I will agree they are very impressive.  The fact that the camera seems to be completely free-roaming throughout the entire duration really helps put you IN the scenes.  I didn't see it in 3D but apparently you feel like you're actually there, which I can believe because just watching it on a regular TV like I did, there were times where I felt myself getting a little nauseous.  The visual effects are very good, and the Earth especially looks beautiful in every shot.  I can understand why it took almost 3 years for the thousands of people working on the visuals to finish everything and they definitely deserve their Oscar for it.  

But getting past the aesthetics of the film, what are we left with?  The answer is not much.  The plot itself isn't new, we've seen it done time and time again, astronauts stranded in space fighting the odds in order to survive.  Lets remember Apollo 13 with Tom Hanks.  That film is far far superior to Gravity and it manages to be so without amazing special effects.  The reason why is because it has a strong human element.  Yeah, I'll admit that maybe because it was based off a true story meant it had more emotional gravity (LOL)  but the fact remains a film made in 1995, centred around pretty much the same sorts of events, manages to be better than a technological masterclass from 2013.  

Gravity is almost revolutionary with its 3D and visual effects, but so what!?  It's more of a sit-in simulator you find at a theme park than it is a film.  For me personally, if you don't have a strong human centre, you can have all the brilliant graphics and computer toys you want, you're not really impressing me.  I didn't care about Sandra Bullock's character, I wasn't routing for her, and to be perfectly honest just like I thought when watching the trailer, I found her extremely annoying throughout.  The noises she makes and her constant whimpering and screaming made me wish she WOULD die!  George Clooney plays George Clooney, nothing to see here, but the film lost something when his character got killed off.  The dialogue is cheesy and cliche, and I feel that they could have made the film a lot more tense if they cut most of it out.  Less is more.  If we had Sandra Bullock shut up for 5 minutes and silently contemplate the situation instead of constantly chatting to herself and trying to give herself motivational pep talks, I might have been more involved.  

A lot of people really like Gravity, and I'm not saying I think it's particularly bad, but I will admit that the scale of its popularity and critical acclaim really bothers me because it's clear as day that when Alfonso Cuaron and co. began pre-production, they probably thought, "Alright, lets make it LOOK really really really good, and you know, everything else will probably fall into place..or something.." Sorry, but no.  Special effects should be used to enhance a story, they should never BE the story.  This should be considered as a decent thriller with impressive effects, but the fact it won 7 Oscars is quite frankly a joke.  It's nothing new.  It's not even an improved version of a tried and tested formula.  

Overall; yeah, great visuals, nobody can deny.  The hard work and thousands of man hours really show as the effects are masterfully executed.  But scratch beneath the shiny surface and we've seen it all before.  Maybe I'm old fashioned but if I can't identify with anything I see on screen I'm not going to sing the praises of the film, and for me I just couldn't get involved with the human side of things.  I guess the best way to describe it would be... *Shrugs shoulders*

Cinema fans rejoice. Gravity is my favorite film of 2013, one of your favorite films of 2013, and one of the critics' favorite films of 2013. I think it's also safe to say that Gravity is also now one of my favorite films in recent years. Alfonso Cuaron deserves one hell of a round of applause. This movie is incredible. Words can't explain the amazement. 

Gravity is a sci-fi outer space techno-thriller directed by Prisoner of Azkaban and Children of Men helmer Alfonso Cuaron, who co-wrote Gravity's script with his son, Jonas Cuaron. This film was in development since 2010. It was to star Angelina Jolie and Robert Downey, Jr. as the lead roles. However, Jolie dropped out to direct In the Land of Blood and Honey, which was a great film. Multiple actresses then auditioned for the female lead role, like Scarlett Johansson, Blake Lively, Marion Cotillard, and Natalie Portman. Sandra Bullock was then chosen for the role. Robert Downey, Jr. dropped out to do Iron Man 2, Due Date, Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows, Marvel's The Avengers, and Iron Man 3, so he was replaced by Danny Ocean himself, George Clooney. 

Filmed digitally on a budget of exactly $100 million, which was a bit lower than the usual 3D/CGI film (The Hobbit, The Avengers, Iron Man 3, Avatar, Star Trek), the film was shot by expert cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki. Father and son Cuaron intended the film to be as scientifically accurate despite a few inaccuracies and exaggerations. For example, in the movie, the explosions and falling debris crashing into things are completely non-audible. Warner Bros. Pictures made the action audible in the trailers to make the movie appear more exciting. In 2013, Gravity was released in IMAX and Real-D theaters everywhere, in the beginning of slasher icon month. 

Gravity involves bio-medical engineer Dr. Ryan Stone, played wonderfully by Sandra Bullock, who's on her first space mission. Joining her is to-be-retired veteran astronaut Matt Kowalski, played by George Clooney. Clooney does a great job playing this character and the dialogue helps Clooney and Bullock's performances. It amazes me...in the GOOD way. I really like the opening shot of this film and how it lasts for like fifteen-or-so minutes. What kept me invested was Alfonso Cuaron's brilliant direction and Emmanuel Lubezki's beautiful cinematography. Lubezki's cinematography beats out Larry Smith's cinematography for Only God Forgives. Oh, yeah. I went there, motherfuckers. 

So, as Ryan, Matt, and the other members of the crew of the spaceship Explorer get into space, falling satellite debris crashes into the ship during a spacewalk. Let me just talk about the 3D and the special effects for a second. They are stunning. They are just unbelievably gorgeous. The CGI and special effects are absolutely remarkable, quite possibly some of the best I've seen since Avatar. The 3D actually works in this film. I saw this in IMAX 3D yesterday (opening day), and I honest to God felt like I was actually in space. To quote a line Sandra Bullock says in this movie: it's terrifyingly beautiful. I also found it very clever how they got Mission Control to be voiced by Ed Harris, in a reference to another wonderful outer space film: Ron Howard's classic, Apollo 13. 

Back to the story, and be warned because there's a shit-ton of spoilers ahead, Stone and Kowalski are now floating in space with a limited amount of air. The debris hits other satellites, causing a chain reaction of destruction until the satellites necessary for them to communicate with Mission Control in Houston are also destroyed. Even though they don't receive messages from Mission Control, both Kowalski and Stone continue to transmit in the blind to Mission Control, in the hopes that Mission Control can hear them. 

Stone tumbles out of control after separating from the shuttle's cargo bay arm. Kowalski, who's wearing a thruster pack as part of his spacesuit, navigates to Stone and retrieves her. They tether together, and make their way back to Explorer, where they discover the shuttle has been damaged beyond repair, and the rest of their crew is dead. They then decide to use the thruster pack to make their way to the ISS, which is nearby in orbit. Kowalski sets the timer on his suit for an hour and a half, estimating the debris that destroyed Explorer will orbit the Earth and come back around in that amount of time. 

Kowalski's ever calm and efficient in the crisis, continuing to reassure Stone that they'll both make it back to Earth safely. En route to the ISS, they discuss Stone's life back home and the death of her young daughter in a schoolyard accident. As they approach the ISS, it's clear that the ISS crew has evacuated due to the debris field causing damage. One Soyuz module for delivering ISS crew and returning them to Earth is missing, used by the ISS crew to evacuate the station. The other Soyuz module has been damaged, and its landing parachute has been deployed as a result. It becomes clear that the remaining Soyuz module can't return them to Earth safely. 

As they approach the ISS they realize they have almost no air left and only one thruster burst remaining in Kowalski's pack. They bounce off the many parts of the ISS as they attempt to grab on at their accelerated speed relative to the station. Stone is able to grab onto the ISS for a moment, however, Kowalski's momentum yanks Stone away from the ISS. As they both bounce off the ISS further, a solar wind they pass severs the tether holding the two together. At the last moment, Stone's leg becomes entangled in parachute cords connected to the Soyuz reentry module, and is able to grab hold of the tether connected to Kowalski. His additional mass stretches the parachute cords entangled to Stone's leg to nearly break free because the damaged ISS is losing altitude and the rarefied air molecules are beginning to exert too much drag on both astronauts. He sacrifices himself for her survival and unclips his strap, floating away. 

When Kowalski sacrificed himself to save Ryan's life, I was nearly in tears. This is one of the most emotional scenes I've ever seen in a film. This film handles its emotional grounding superbly. Never was it overdrawn nor was it forced. It was perfect, along with the screenplay. Father and son Cuaron have a supreme amount of talent. It's amazing. So amazing that it can't be put into words. 

Back to the plot, Stone indeed floats easily back to the ISS now. Kowalski's still in radio contact with her, asking Stone about her minimal piloting training and instructs Stone to use the Soyuz capsule to travel to the nearby Chinese space station Tiangong by using the small maneuvering rockets to navigate, even though the reentry vehicle itself can't return to earth due to the prematurely deployed parachute. Kowalski says that even if the Chinese have evacuated, she can use the remaining return module that's based on the design of the Soyuz, and Stone's limited training will get her home safely. 

Stone boards the ISS, which has been damaged but still has breathable air. Stone makes her way to the Soyuz module, but a fire starts from sparking wires aboard the ISS. She tries vainly to put out the fire, and finally gets aboard the Soyuz. Once aboard, Stone undocks the module and proceeds to fire the thruster, but the parachute cables of the Soyuz are tangled to the ISS, keeping the Soyuz from getting free. Stone puts on one of the Soyuz spacesuits and spacewalks outside to release the parachute cables from the capsule. An hour and a half has passed and during the spacewalk, the satellite debris approaches again, impacting with the ISS and the Soyuz. Stone barely makes it inside the Soyuz in time, just as the debris field impacts and destroys the ISS, but the Soyuz module manages to break free of the ISS. 

Stone goes over the emergency manual, and uses the thrusters to line the Soyuz up with Tiangong. She attempts to fire the main Soyuz rocket to navigate to Tiangong; however, the fuel tanks are empty. Stone tries to use the Soyuz radio to contact Earth, but she's only able to reach a farmer who doesn't speak English on a short wave frequency. Stone resigns herself to her fate of dying, and instead of waiting to die from excruciating carbon dioxide poisoning, she slowly begins decompression in the cabin to commit suicide by the painless hypoxia. She begins to fall asleep, running out of oxygen, when she sees Kowalski outside the capsule. Kowalski enters the capsule, to Stone's amazement. Stone tells him that there's no fuel left for the navigation rockets, but Kowalski, ever the optimist, tells Stone that the capsule still has reentry rockets for the touchdown procedure. These will be just as useful for navigating to Tiangong. 

Kowalski's suddenly gone and Stone realizes she hallucinated him in her oxygen-deprived state. She turns the oxygen flow back on in the Soyuz and implements the information about the landing thrusters she remembered from her hallucination, firing the thrusters, making her way to Tiangong. Realizing she's gonna miss the station by several dozen meters, Stone picks up a fire extinguisher and opens the Soyuz hatch while the capsule's still pressurized, blowing her across the distance. She navigates to Tiangong using the fire extinguisher as a makeshift thruster. Stone boards Tiangong just as the entire station, having been pushed out of its stable orbit by the satellite debris, starts to burn up on the upper edge of the atmosphere. Stone successfully enters the re-entry commands in the Chinese capsule Shenzhou's computer, and Shenzhou begins its descent towards Earth. On the way down, Stone hears Mission Control over the radio tracking the capsule while rescue teams are being dispatched. 

Shenzhou splashes down in a lake in an uninhabited part of the Earth. Stone opens the capsule hatch, but the water rushing in nearly drowns her, pinning her against the back wall. Once the water pressure equalizes, she swims out, but sinks with the weight of her spacesuit. She successfully slips out of her spacesuit and swims to the surface with the last of her breath. She swims to shore watching the remains of Tiangong and other satellite debris as they burn up high in the sky overhead. Stone pulls herself ashore with difficulty and takes her first shaky steps on dry land, gradually adjusting to the Earth's gravity. And the film ends there. 

FINAL SCORE: 10/10

I know, I know - the movie released ages ago. So why am I giving my review now? Well, for one thing, the movie is still running in theatres. But, more importantly, it's a movie that redefines the movie going experience. It very successfully does what few movies do nowadays - leave you in awe. I recently saw the movie for a second time, and I was as moved as I was the first time. And now that I am back to writing reviews, I just had to write this one.

Starring Sandra Bullock and George Clooney, and directed by the brilliant Alfonso Cuaron (it will be a disappointment if he doesn't win the Best Director Oscar for this one), "Gravity" is essentially a ship-wreck survival story set in space. Medical engineer Dr. Ryan Stone (Bullock) and veteran astronaut Matt Kowalski (Clooney) are part of the shuttle Explorer's STS-157 mission. During a spacewalk to service the Hubble Station telescope, Mission Control in Houston warns the team about a Russian missile strike on an inoperative satellite, which has caused a chain reaction forming a cloud of space debris. High speed debris strikes the Explorer, killing all the team-members except Stone and Kowalski, who are stranded in space. The movie is about their attempt to get back to earth.

The movie works on every level - it is a tense thriller, and at the same time a story about the triumph of human will against seemingly insurmountable odds. And a big reason it works is the acting. It's not an understatement that the acting rests squarely on the able shoulders of Sandra Bullock and George Clooney (they are, after all, the only actors in the movie - ignoring the voice actors). Clooney hits all the notes playing the wise-cracking Kowalski - he oozes charm and wit, but still conveys the experience of a veteran, and the concern and caring for Dr. Stone. As for Sandra Bullock, she gives a great, nuanced performance as Dr. Ryan Stone - from the nervousness of the character, to the sheer panic, to the despair, to the resolve to survive - the journey of the character has been portrayed beautifully.

Of course, I have to devote some words for the special effects, which are in a league of their own. This film makes the best use of 3D I have ever seen - hands down. The scenes where the debris is hurtling towards the screen would have most audiences ducking. If a movie had technology specifically made for it, you can imagine it would be worth something. A lot of the stuff on screen would have been very difficult to pull off, and it definitely pays off. The movie is visually stunning, and the vastness of space contrasted with the claustrophobic feeling of being in cramped spaces gives so much more depth to the scenes. For me, the experience I had was almost as if I was also floating in space.

At the end of the day, this movie is all about the director. Cuaron delivers another believable science fiction movie (if you haven't seen "Children of Men", I would highly recommend it) with a taut screenplay, and great attention to detail - I read that the science is pretty accurate (though I wouldn't know, and it really doesn't matter for a regular movie-goer). And of course there's his love for long continuous scenes - just pay attention to the first scene, it's 13 minutes long! There are a lot of beautiful shots, and despite all its technical brilliance, there is no compromise in the story or the characters. And the one thing that shines through is Alfonso Cuaron's assured touch which makes, what could have been a really simple and ordinary movie, an extraordinary piece of work.

If you still haven't seen Gravity, change that immediately. If you have seen Gravity, but not in 3D - change that immediately. This movie is a cinematic landmark, one that will stay on in your minds long after you have left the theatre.


P.S.: Once you see the movie, you may want to check out the short "Aningaaq".

There is no other film experience on Earth like Gravity. Which makes sense, keeping in mind the whole movie was located in space, with only the ending scene being on Earth.

 Alfonso Cuaron has struck gold with his masterpiece Gravity. It explores the silence of space where all you can hear are your breaths and your thoughts as you spin around aimlessly. This is usually harmless until a crisis like debris comes into play. From then on, Sandra Bullock puts on an amazing performance which will definitely give her an Oscar nod, and George Clooney is his usual affable self.

 One thing that really defined this movie's greatness was its careful attention to being realistic. From the tears slipping down Sandra Bullock's cheeks actually floating off her face, to the oxygen in her suit depleting at a steady rate, this movie doesn't look over any detail or flaw. Instead, it uses simplicity and directness to flow the movie along. Nothing was that unbelievable in this movie.

 Even though sound was a luxury in this movie, the emotional side of the film was not. Confined to tight spaces, Bullock couldn't really do anything to hide her emotions. She couldn't run anywhere to hide, or walk into a different room. Instead, we all saw and felt what she was going through, and actually cared about what happening to her character.

 Another thing this movie did that was great was switch perspectives of the camera. We went from seeing what was happening from the character's eyes, to a third person view, to a wide camera angle, all in a few seconds. And the best part is, the camera was so fluent and coherent that we didn't even notice that the perspectives were changing until it actually happened. Genius filmmaking.

 I could go on about this things this movie did right, because to be honest I can't think of anything I didn't like in the movie, which is extremely rare. Overall, this is a new kind of cinema experience that cannot be replicated again. (Yes, that was a challenge, directors!) Everyone in the target audience and beyond should see this movie because of its realistic sense of things and its careful attention to detail. The cinematography is beautiful, and the views and perspectives this movie gives are to die for. The emotional core, themes, and moral lessons this movie offers should be soaked up with ease. And the way it draws you into the story and what's happening is truly an amazing feat.
Simply an amazing watch.

I really really really didn't want to watch Gravity on a little screen, but I also couldn't let it be the only unseen Best Picture nominee. I'm cutting it a bit of slack because it is obviously a beautiful film and any quibbles I have would just vanish in a visually immersive environment (take away a full star if you watch it on a laptop). But even with a modest screen size and bargain-bin sound system, Gravity is a really solid thriller. By never bothering with any kind of prologue and opening right in space (along with a ninety minute runtime), Gravity never hits a dry patch and maintains tension throughout. Sure, Bullock's character is surprisingly flat and that space debris obeys Murphy's Law like nothing else, but look how pretty it is!

This film is an absolute masterpiece and a work of art that needs to be seen.  Technically, this film is easily one of the most impressive films I have ever seen.  The special effects are absolutely outstanding and create an incredible sense of immersion, and the film didn't even cost THAT much to begin with.  It had $100 million budget, not counting the money spent on marketing, and I'm pretty sure a good chunk of that was eaten up by getting both Sandra Bullock and George Clooney, which probably got this funded in the first place.  I'm sure Clooney didn't command as much as he usually does considering that his role in the film isn't as meaty as Sandra's.  That makes the effects of the film far more impressive, when you take into consideration how other SFX-heavy movies cost more to make but only look half as good as this film does.  I'm not sure if I could go out of my way and say that this film's effects are revolutionary, considering that movies abusing special effects have been the norm for almost 20 years, so because of that it isn't exactly rare, as it was when Star Wars first came out, to see a film with heavy use of special effects.  That's the only reason I can think of for why the film's effects won't be looked as revolutionary, even though they actually are.  This is the most realistic and believable portrayal of space in any movie I've ever seen.  I can only imagine how impressive this film must've been on the big screen, in an IMAX theater for example.  It would've captured the incredible scope of space much more accurately than a 28-inch screen HDTV.  And the film's story, looking at it without thinking about all the allegories and the symbolism, looking at it as a story of survival in the face of impossible odds.  This is THE worst situation you could probably find yourself in, being stuck in space with all the comms systems down, having your space station destroyed by debris flying at 50,000 miles per hour, and this debris will continue to fly by every 90 minutes after it completes its orbit, and finding yourself in a situation where you, in your first mission, have to find a way to make it back to earth without anybody to help you or guide you through it.  That doesn't sound like a situation anybody would want to find themselves in.  The film sees Murphy's Law, everything that can go wrong will, and turns the knob up to 11.  The film's intensity is heightened by the fact that there is absolutely no way for noise to travel in space, so seeing Stone trying to detach a chute from her module, that she will use to try and reach the Chinese space station, as she's completely unaware of the debris completely destroy the Russian station is absolutely horrifying.  But there's also the contrast of this horrific thing happening to this woman with the serene and peaceful vastness of space.  There's a real beauty to behold in being in one of these missions, so that's a good contrast to the horrifying situation that Stone finds herself in.  The thing about the film is that it works perfectly if you're someone that's looking to be "entertained", if you can call it that.  It's a very thrillingly directed film, it's a definite roller-coaster ride.  But if you don't want to think about the symbolism, the film's allegories, and its themes then you can definitely get something out of the film.  But I think the film really hits its strides with its symbolism and its themes of human resilience and evolution, particularly in the last scene of the film.  The last scene of the film, with Stone ***SPOILERS*** finally landing on earth, showcases humanity's evolution in about one minute.  It's so simply done, yet it conveys so many thoughts and debates about humanity and our evolution.  And the image of Stone falling asleep in an embryonic, with a rope near her that looks, unsurprisingly, like an umbilical cord.  Again, very simple but conveys a lot.  There's also religious symbolism and themes explored here but it isn't as focused on as much as the other key themes of the film.  The acting is top-notch.  Sandra Bullock absolutely kills it with her character.  She's expertly written and she's actually one of the better female characters to come out of any film in ages.  She's determined to make it out of this situation.  Granted, there is a moment of weakness where she completely gives up and resigns herself to the fact that she's gonna die, before she has a hallucination of Kowalski coming back and giving her a pep talk about how the fact that her daughter died, before the film's events, doesn't have to define who she is now and what she does with her life from this moment on is what matters.  That gives her like a jolt to fight back and make it back to earth.  It was incredible character development.  From now on, I'm gonna pretend that Sandra Bullock won the Oscar for this film instead of The Blind Side.  And Clooney is as charming and likable as ever.  He adds a calm confidence to the film, at least for the time that he is in the film and I think that helped the film a lot.  Credit goes to Alfonso and Jonas Cuaron for managing to make their very ambitious vision an absolute reality.  The film is outstandingly directed and written, complete credit goes to the Cuarons for their work in bringing every individual aspect of the film together into one coherent whole.  The score to the film is amazing as well, it serves as a substitute for the absolute silence of space.  It creates incredible tension.  As you can see, I absolutely loved this film.  It's really rare to find a film that manages to do everything almost perfectly.  I'm not saying that the film doesn't have flaws, but they're as unnoticeable as any film I've ever seen.  I absolutely loved this film and it easily shoots right to the top of my favorites of 2013.  This is a must-see.

Suspension of disbelief is critical to any audience member.  For that reason, this movie is an utter piece of space junk. Nobody with any inkling of comprehension with regards to the physical sciences should watch this flotsam without a blindfold at the ready.  I'm sure there were a few moments during which you could empathize with the main character, but the glaring deviations from any semblance of potential reality makes it extremely difficult to focus on whatever plot they tried to squeeze into this cartoon.  Watching it with a critical eye made it seem more fanciful than a Tim Burton film.  As a devotee of true space missions and their precision,complexity and adherence to the Law of Universal Gravitation (please note the lack of quotation marks around that last phrase) I am no less than offended by what was perpetrated by this film.  I found myself more moved by the most recent attempts at Muppet fare than I was by this offense to realism.  I'm glad Sandra got her groove back, but this story could have been told without offending the scientists and astronauts that work diligently to perfect the space programs of the civilized nations on this planet.

By the way... Anyone comparing this film to Arthur C Clarke's fabulous novel "2001: A Space Odyssey" , and the subsequent masterpiece on cellulose created by Stanley Kubrick should be launched into space without a pressure suit.  Aside from the fact that these two films are set beyond our atmosphere there are no other correlations between them. None at all. Completion of a mail-in correspondence course in filmography would leave the participant dumbfounded as to why anyone would even consider making such a comparison.  It's simply ponderous.  If Alfonso Cuaron truly wanted the debris and adversities to act as a metaphor for the problems of everyday life then maybe the film should have been named "Metaphor".  At least then the title would actually describe what you were seeing in action.  Save your money and go watch something more down to Earth.

I watched Gravity tonight and it completely took me out of my day. It took me out of the bad week I was having before the Friday night. Without spoiling much, Gravity is a story of two astronauts trying to go home after a space debris storm destroyed their ship. I am not sure if it was the ominous music or the first-person perspectives, but I was totally sucked into the film after the first ten minutes. Cuaron's metaphors are blatant, but still beautifully shot. It's a story of fear, loneliness, desperation, strength, and most of all hope. And it was done with only two actors! Totally love this film. I'm raising my vodka flask for this one.

Gravity boasts  jaw-dropping visuals, and the themes of isolation and survival are at center stage, keeping you engaged in the story. Bullock and Clooney are better than ever here and it's probably some of Bullock's best work. 

What I'm trying to say is: you should watch this movie. (Note: to all those haters who think this film is just about Sandra Bullock floating in space, go watch the film for yourself and then form your opinion about. Just don't watch it of you have really bad anxiety problems, I wouldn't want you having a heart attack.)

Nonetheless, Gravity is a masterfully crafted film. Seriously, go watch the behind the scenes of the making of this movie. It will blow your mind how they shot it. (Note: most of the film is done in the computer with digital effects).

The father and son team of Alfonso and Jon√°s Cuar√≥n have written a gripping, metaphorical human drama in the most dangerous imaginable setting possible in the film Gravity. In terms of dialing up the tension, this film sets a monumental bar in filmmaking and screenwriting. Despite being full of tension and drama, the screenwriters manage to provide us with one of the most powerful contemporary examples of what Blake Snyder calls, the Midpoint moment in a story. In this essay, we will explore this section of the film and winnow out examples of the efficacy Alfonso and Jon√°s Cuar√≥n were able to attain that paid dividends at those precise moments and how those moments built capitol in the later scenes of the film.
		Dr. Ryan Stone, at the midpoint of the film, has lost her only human contact as Matt Kowalksi sacrificed himself to save her. The viewer is forced to reconcile this loss alongside Stone and still keep in mind that she is floating in space and has just gambled to reach the International Space Station. In the most major way, she has just experienced an almost impossible win and simultaneously suffered an incalculable loss. Her small moment of comfort in the ISS is a metaphorical rebirth, complete with fetal position and muffled womb sounds. This respite is short lived as the debris storm is coming back around and the bad guys are truly closing in. 
		The situation that Stone finds herself in is the epitome of physical danger. As fragile human beings we can feel the tension and experience the fear of death, especially when viewed in the intended 3D aspect. In addition to the physical and logistic mayhem, another real, creeping danger is the tenuous limitations of the human psyche and how ominous isolation can be. 
		In terms of execution, Alfonso Cuar√≥n stated that the experience of making the movie was not unlike the journey that Ryan Stone goes through in the film. (Cuar√≥n) If this comparison is true, the Midpoint moment for Cuar√≥n in envisioning this film had to be devising ways to portray zero gravity on the screen. The iconic zero gravity moment is when Ryan Stone is ensconced in the ISS floating in fetal position in the WWII fighter/Millennium Falcon porthole with the earth in the background. This isolation and helplessness grabs the viewer and pulls them into the desperation that Stone is no doubt experiencing. 
		The danger of space madness is fully realized in the coming scenes in the Soyuz. Before her self-imposed stasis within the Soyuz, she is challenged with having to fight a fire in the ISS in zero gravity all while awaiting the continued debris storm. The midpoint of the film offered one of the only moments of respite in the entire film. The transfer from screenplay to screen in terms of timing shows how important previsioning is when dealing with a feature length film. The story on the page reads much more methodically than the experience of watching the film itself. With the visual and sensorial experience, the viewer is tugged along much like Ryan Stone in the wake of Matt Kowalski's jet pack.

Gravity is a sci-fi thriller starring Sandra Bullock and George Clooney as two astronauts struggling to survive in space after debris hit their space station. The movie does contain impressive special effects as it made me believe they actually shot the movie in space. The first person view of the astronauts during the accident makes the movie even more intense.  However, the story is your typical isolation survival premise with some parts having bad dialogue.
