One of the biggest ways I judge movies is re-watchability. Not the idea of "could I watch that again",  which is the case with Gravity. Rather, "do I want to watch that again"? They are two completely different things. I put Gravity on the list of entertaining movies, that if the occasion called for it I'd watch again, but could never see myself acually "wanting" to watch it again. Which makes it a pretty just okay movie...I guess. The special effects are there, and exceptional. The direction is crisp. Cuaron gives you the feelings of the very big and ominous, then the feelings of claustrophobic insignificance and back again. His shots are beautiful and his use of sound is borderline special, and its key to the film so good thing he got it right. I dont give the same credit to the acting. There's only two actors seen in the whole film so you'd hope they'd be memorable in some way. I dont know why George Clooney is in this movie, he does nothing. His every line sounds like something Clooney would say in real life, was he even in the script? Sandra Bullock got an Oscar nod for her performance and I can't for the life of me figure out why. She's scared in space drifting around....ya ummm...that's it. Oh they did throw in the typical "she had a daughter that died which has always held her back from her full potential but this one event will allow her to finally let go of the past and overcome". God its weak and unnecessary. If you enjoy films for character acting and plot then no need. If you do see it for its visual excellence and are anything like me, one viewing will do.

Once in a lifetime comes a movie that is so vastly respected and loved by audiences and critics, that viewing is absolutely essential. That's right, I'm reviewing Gravity. The big one, the one that critics and audiences alike have been gushing over and falling all over themselves with.

What starts off as a routine mission for rookie astronaut Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) and the final spacewalk for veteran astronaut Matt Kowalski (George Clooney) turns out to be anything but when horrible circumstance after horrible circumstance befall upon the two, causing them to fight for their lives in the sparse, lifeless environment of space.

While some critics call Gravity "the best film of the year", I believe it would be more appropriate to refer to this as "the most overrated film of the year". Hell, I wouldn't even put it in my ten best films of the year. Call me cynical, call me heartless, call me old-fashioned, compare me to Adolf Hitler, give me all the thumbs down your want, but I just couldn't see anything particularly exceptional or groundbreaking about Gravity that other films did in the past, and better too I may add.

To be perfectly honest, when I saw the first trailer, I thought that Cuaron played his trump card too early with Bullock's character floating off at the end of the trailer. I thought, "how can you make a movie beyond this point if you have basically spoiled the whole movie in a sixty second trailer?" Of course, I found out watching the movie that there was more to the affair than that, but I still would've constructed the trailer differently.

One of my primary problems with the film is that the main character, Ryan Stone, is really not that interesting of a character. Her character is simply as dull as dishwater, and her character development is clich√© and hacky. How is the audience supposed to be invested in a character if we learn next to nothing about her? In order to care about a character, you must set aside time in the film to get to know them, learn their ins and outs. If Ryan was not such a downer, then maybe I would respond to her more. And the fact that (spoilers) her child died is just purely formula to me. It's like they say, "Oh, you must feel empathy for this character but her daughter died. You must cry for her and root for her even though she hasn't down a single thing to deserve it."

Also, I never found Sandra Bullock to be that great of an actor. Especially evident in Gravity, all she does is scream, cry, scream, cry, talk to herself, rinse, repeat. I wouldn't even rank it amongst the best performances of the year, because it just seems average to me. Nothing is really particularly special about it that the acting of any average feature has. Neither is George Clooney in this film. He is basically playing George Clooney. Ironic, how when he is finally with a woman his own age, he drifts away from her forever. Yeah, I know, I stole that from the Golden Globes, but yeah, if you must steal, steal from the best.

I never saw a single Alfonso Cuaron film before Gravity, or maybe I should refer to the film as "Murphy's Law: The Movie". How Cuaron and his son Jonas write the film is basically that. They relish at the fact of putting this character through hardship after hardship after hardship after hardship until it truly becomes ridiculous. I mean, nothing can seriously go THAT BAD. I mean, yes, missions can go badly every once in a while and crap can happen to people, but for it to go as bad as it gets in Gravity seems kinda far-fetched to me. Not even Seinfeld episodes had this much bad stuff happen to the protagonists. It seems that the two Cuarons just wrote that in to get your "emotionally invested" with a character who is boring and dull even more. It's a win-win scenario!

Cuaron not only participated in the direction, writing and producing in this film, but also the editing with Mark Sanger. There are only 130-some-odd cuts in the whole film, with long tracking shots all throughout. I have nothing against tracking shots in films, and the ones in Gravity actually do work out to their advantage, but I don't like how they are executed most of the time. By the third minute of a non-stop slice of film, I start to get bored. I watch movies to escape reality, to be transported in a world abstract from your own and get totally immersed in it. If I wanted to see a long tracking shot of some gentle images with no story, I do have something called my life. I, myself, also understand the importance of good editing because I am an editor of YouTube videos I make. Editing is an important part of a film, and making the experience even more enjoy in the long run... if done right. The editing is more subtle here, but it still could've served better by having more time in the oven in that department.

This next part, I will spoil some key moments of the film. If you do not want to be spoiled, please skip to the next paragraph, or exit the review in disgust over how I am crapping on this "masterpiece". Either way works.

During one scene, Dr. Ryan Stone reputedly goes to the International Space Station, and yet there's not a single person there. It doesn't take a nuclear scientist to point out that the International Space Station has people actually living there. Seems kinda hokey, to me, Alfonso. Also, the ending climax, which I was actually laughing at a bit, when her Murphy's Law lands her in the water and she miraculously survives (not even the kid from Life of Pi had to go through shit like this) and even though she does survive, we as the audience are completely unaware if she actually lives, if she actually finds civilization, or food, or shelter. All we know is that she survives the ordeal. At least give me an answer as to whether our boring protagonist actually goes back to listening to the radio on her way home from her job.

So far in the review, I have been pretty much trashing on this film. I should probably note that I don't hate this film at all. There's nothing about this movie that is particularly offensive or objectionable. In fact, there's even some stuff I enjoyed in this film. The effects in this film are simply A-1. The entire illusion of being up in space is totally bought due to the impressive effects that will, repeat WILL, win the Academy Award for Visual Effects, even if I could have sworn I saw a couple of wires on those space stations. Also winning the Oscars are Emmanuel Lubezki for their impressive, sweeping cinematography full of beautiful earth images and equally beautiful, but in a different way, space shots. The sound effects work on the film is actually pretty awesome, filled with some pretty unique sounds, or lack thereof in certain scenarios, that will win both sound categories on Sunday. Even though it's not the best of the year, Steven Price's score can turn into a great listen when it's in the right scene.

Gravity is a mixed bag. While I have been spending most of the review pointing out the films faults, and being just spellbound that the film scored 98% and got ten Academy Award nominations from 90 minutes of Sandra Bullock spinning, screaming and surviving against all odds, I am impressed with a lot of the technical aspects on the film. But great visual effects do not make a great film, unfortunately. Strip away the visuals, and you get a less than spectacular film. What made films like Inception or Hugo so good was because instead of focusing on only the effects, but also focus on the characters and the story and the emotion so that the audience can be even more enthralled, and what made films like Avatar or Life of Pi so not good is that they are just lackluster storytelling and clich√© ideas reigned supreme to the point of the audience not even caring about that, and developing the common intelligence of a Transformers film fan. Gravity is not necessarily a bad film, per se, or a film that should not have been made. I am glad that I saw it, and I am glad that I saw another BP winner this year, but either I am the only one not under the drugs or the brainwashing of these "visual spectacle" films that I now kinda despise, or I am truly the only one who is letting all these ideas simply go right past my head. If you like this film, or even love it and think it's amongst the best of 2013, then I am happy that you found a lot to like about this film, but to me Gravity is the most overrated film of the year, and one of the overrated films ever made.

**1/2 out of ****
FINAL VERDICT: 62%

Gravity in 3D... was... AWESOME!  If there's one movie you see in IMAX 3D, make sure this is the one because this is the kind of film that really immerses its viewers and makes them feel as though they're a part of the action.  And IMAX 3D is a MUST in order to get that full effect.

I don't want to spoil anything about this movie because the only scenes that they've shown in the trailers are things that happen in the first 20 minutes of the film.  Everything else is a surprise.  So this review will be quick.  In short, Gravity is a movie about astronauts who are in space, fixing the Hubble Telescope when a cloud of debris from a destroyed satellite, traveling faster than a bullet, collides with their shuttle, destroying almost everything around them.  So George Clooney and Sandra Bullock are left floating in space with no communication with Earth and seemingly no way of getting home.  And this is where the suspense, anxiety, and bouts of claustrophobia begin (for the viewer).

This movie has the most realistic effects I have ever seen.  I know I said that in my review about Elysium, but that was a science fiction film with a bunch of elements that don't exist in real life.  This movie has the most REALISTIC visual effects for a movie that's grounded in reality.  Now don't get me wrong, there are some things that happen in this movie that you have to admit are a little far-fetched and likely couldn't happen in real life, but it's the most realistic-looking thing you've ever seen, so you believe that it could and actually is happening, especially in 3D.  And there are many scenes with first-person shots, so you get the feeling that you are the one experiencing everything that's happening on the screen.  Also, there are some shots in this movie that last 10 to 15 minutes straight without any cuts.  It's just the same continuous shot the whole time, even while chaos is ensuing.  Keep that in mind when you see this movie because that alone was pretty impressive. 

Even if you don't care much about space movies, I highly encourage you to see this movie anyway for the effect that it'll have on you as a viewer.  This movie was so suspenseful that I caught myself holding my breath at times because I was too anxious about what might happen next that I couldn't even breathe.  This film has something in it for everyone... great effects, a strong sense of realism and believability, great acting, and a good story about desperation, empowerment, and perseverance.  I give "Gravity" 4 out of 4 stars, an A+, and a smiley face.  I really thought it was that good.

The acting (two performances, basically) was great, and the Ryan Stone character was very well-done in that she was intelligent and tough, but still vulnerable and thus relatable; we could easily imagine ourselves in her shoes, or astronaut boots I guess.

Believe it; Gravity is worthy of the hype that it's accumulated in the past couple months; all the awards go to a movie that is deserving of it. First off, while other movies have attempted space, I guarantee you've never seen anything like this before. Alfonso Cuaron's directing coupled with his beautiful use of cinematography and imagery is reason enough just to go see this movie. It's just absolutely stunning. Every second of every scene, I was completely blown away by the constant reminder of how big the world is and how small we are, as humans, almost to the point of being insignificant. The sunrise; just...wow. Sadly, I didn't see it in cinema but I really wish I had because I imagine, and also based on other reviews I've read, that the use of 3D would have been very welcome; and I hear that people who saw it in IMAX were floored. The use of first person perspective for about 40% of the movie brought a new layer of emotional connection to the main character, Ryan, as we see everything through her eyes and it creates a level of depth that we feel; we feel her heart rushing; we feel her fear, the tension, the emotions; everything. Cuaron's use of sound should also be noted as the sound was astounding. I was lucky enough to be able to watch the movie with surround sound, and let me tell you, I was glued to my seat. Every thump, every explosion, every scene with tense music just complimented every scenario and helped to deeper pull the audience into the experience. I honestly still can't get over how well this movie was directed and it's really one of the most gorgeous movies I've seen in a very long time, so much that I had to literally watch over scenes because I missed the dialogue or I was too distracted by just how gorgeous Earth and space looks. Cuaron's imagination really knows based on his point of view and talent in this movie. But as for music, my favourite parts had to be the periods of silence. In surround sound, I was listening so intently to see if I could pick up anything at all, only after to hear the small thump of a piece of metal, or the beeping of an oxygen tank, or better yet, Ryan's breathing as she's hyperventilating and running out of oxygen. I know I've stressed but gosh, this just harkens back to how well this movie was directed. So directing, music and cinematography aside, the performances were also really great, and make no mistake, despite Clooney's screen time, it's actually Bullock's show. Every second he was on screen, he was charming as always, headstrong and confident which is a reason why I thought it was a nice touch to have his character coupled with Bullock's character who is unsure, emotionally unattached and who seemed to have given up on life. This brings me to Gravity's story; it's not the content that was impressive but how it was presented. The story has been done before; loss of a loved one has lead to depression and giving up on life; but it's the fact that she likes space because its quiet, no one to harass her and its a place she can be alone and not have responsibilities or duties and not be tethered to anything. Suffering a tragic loss, you'd come to expect that of a person, especially considering who it is. But its in the darkest moment of the movie when she finally decides to give up, that portrays one of humanities deepest secrets; we're afraid of being alone and not being remembered. Her character breaks down right before giving up and Bullock just delivers in that performance and it just stuck with me, despite that she was amazing throughout the movie. Her quick growth, because the movie was actually pretty short, which was a good thing because they jam packed so much tense content I feel as if they drew it out, it would have had less impact, was very believable and satisfying. Seeing her decide to fight for her life and saying goodbye to her child (metaphorically) was a really sweet scene and I was happy for her at the end. It's hard to find any complaints for this movie as it's so original and well done but if I had to say one thing, maybe a little more Clooney might not have been a bad thing; so as to show, since he helped motivate her, her willingness to fight again. There is just nothing quite like hearing complete and utter silence and during that, hearing Bullock narrate how much oxygen is left in her tank. The use of Bullock's character alone for most of the movie also helps denote the level of solitude felt in space that went a very long way. I feel like i'm going in circles because there's just so much good to say about this movie; but don't take my word for it; if you haven't already seen it, this is a must watch. Unbelievably gorgeous movie from start to finish, tense and emotionally gripping and thrills never felt in any other movie, Gravity is worthy of all the praise. Seal of definite approval. 9.5/10

This movie seems to confirm there are different strokes for different folks. 

If you're looking for a movie where almost everything on the screen is constantly moving and spinning around in circles, this movie is for you... Just keep your sea sick pills on standby. 

The CGI was marginal at best, although judging by the reviews, I'm one of the few who noticed. Their emphasis on "there is no sound in space" was a poor choice as they decided to add a constant barrage of meaningless noises and humming/singing to fill the fact that "there is no sound in space". 

There is too much joking around at the beginning of the movie from George Clooney.  I'm sure they did it to try to make him the fast witted like able funny guy, but it's not appropriate for the situation and is difficult to watch. Especially considering he plays such a marginal role. They make it look like all astronauts do in space is screw around and play games while on space walks. I highly doubt an astronaut would use their tether as a toy to hurl themselves into space and bounce back to the ship.  

Finally, Sandra bullock looks like a skeleton in this movie. It's almost hard to watch a few scenes. 

In summation, I found it difficult to make it through this whole movie, since everyone else seems to think it was the best thing since sliced bread, I stuck with it, I wish I had the last 90 minutes of my life back. Not sure how this got such great reviews.

GRAVITY-The Movie is spectacular. It will have you on the edge of your seat. Great cast and storyline. Cuaron does an amazing job directing, Bullock puts on the performance of her career and the visuals are something to marvel at.  It is easy to get lost in the realism of the story and the incredible cinematography. Praising a film for its technical accomplishments is often an underhand way of saying that its story isn't up to scratch. We've all heard the phrase "style over substance" and can readily think of many examples of films which fit that description. This film is a must-see.
I cannot understand why people like this film.

Perhaps the most talked about movie of 2013, Alfonso Cuaron's innovative character chiller is quite simply the scariest and most sumptuous space has ever looked on screen. Breathtaking sound design and immersive cinematography make for a refreshing, wholly unique viewing experience, capturing fear and claustrophobia in a way you've never quite seen them before, and Sandra Bullock is spellbinding, despite her performance being 80% face-in-a-fishbowl. 
The theme of triumph in the face of adversity is mirrored within the story of the actual making of the film itself and, on terms of both the visual and the emotional, it's safe to say that with Gravity, Cuaron has laid the foundations for the future of cinema. A real must-see.
One of the most eye popping, tense, and gripping Sci- Fi thrillers I have seen in a long time. And the 3D is pretty decent too.

Dazzling, visionary, harrowing, and fraught! The turbulence (oh, excuse me, "rough air") on the plane was perfectly in sync with the later escape scenes, and added to watching experience. Sandra Bullock picks smart roles, while George Clooney mails it in as he does for every movie. Now I have to go study the physics to see if it was all correct.

Alfonso Cuar√É¬≥n has once again crafted a visually stunning, and incredibly ambitious film. Although the characters in this film aren't the most fleshed out, they're likeable enough, and you wanna see them succeed. The action sequences are very edge of your seat intense. Thankfully the pacing is near impeccable, so after an intense scene, the film gives you just enough time to catch your breath.
       Alfonso Cuar√É¬≥n has always had an eye, and talent for seamlessly blending scenes together. Although not to the extreme as it was for Children of Men, scenes feel like one massive sequence, instead of chopped up bits. The film is just shot so wonderfully.
      The acting is great, even if the characters aren't. The characters are probably the only real problem I had with the film. They're good enough, and that's all you really need for this film. However, without giving too much away, there is very much a standout scene between Stone and Kowalski.
       I mentioned earlier that this film is visually stunning. Everything looks and feels so practical, I'm convinced it was actually shot in space (not really, but damn is it convincing)! To go along with the visuals, is an equally stunning score. Steven Price has composed something truly special. From gritty for the intense sequences, to atmospheric and ambient for the lighter parts, to all out epic beauty for the film's climax. Not a single beat was missed. 
        It may not have a life changing story, and the characters may not be best ever written, but Gravity is much more than those things. With mind blowing special effects, ambitious and innovative filming techniques, riveting action sequences, and an excellent score; Gravity is a monumental achievement in filmmaking.

I can't comprehend how this even gets moderate praise.It's a poor film with a monumentally implausible plot, caricature characters, silly dialogue, and absolutely no basis in the realms of reality. But it's got nice CGI so it must be 'Film of the Year!'

After finishing watching this movie I went to read the negative review in Movie Mezzanine - the only one I could find... and I have to say that the writer Jake Cole had few valid points in it...  However, I still enjoyed fully this  British-American 3D science-fiction thriller and space drama. Directed, co-written, co-produced and co-edited by Alfonso Cuar√≥n, the film stars Sandra Bullock and George Clooney as astronauts involved in the mid-orbit destruction of a space shuttle and their attempt to return to Earth. Despite being set in outer space, the film draws upon motifs from shipwreck and wilderness survival stories about psychological change and resilience in the aftermath of catastrophe. Cuar√≥n uses Stone to illustrate clarity of mind, persistence, training, and improvisation in the face of isolation and the mortal consequences of a relentless Murphy's Law

Outstanding cinematography from Emmanuel Lubezki was matched by Steven Price's musical score, Cuar√≥n's direction, Bullock's performance and Framestore's visual effects. No wonder it grossed over $700 million at the worldwide box-office, emerging as the eighth highest-grossing film of the year. In 2014, Gravity was nominated for 10 Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director for Cuar√≥n and Best Actress for Bullock. The film was also awarded six BAFTA Awards, including Outstanding British Film and Best Director, the Golden Globe Award for Best Director, and seven Critics Choice Awards. But, I have to mention that I found unusual reaction from Chinese viewers regarding the film... they were not impressed and most of them were upset that "they again use our Chinese equipment without asking us" attitude. I had to mention this, because to me as a foreigner in China that was never an issue, and the reaction was unexpected.

The screenplay was maybe the only weak point of this movie. The dialogues were mostly acceptable but in moments of crisis they were quite unrealistic, especially when moving forward to find the escape route. Cuar√≥n and his son Jon√°s had those monologues filled with such awkwardly tacked-on backstory that the dialogue-rich scene plays like a parody. Kowalsky loves to tell stories of lost love that he has badgered everyone with time and again, and when Stone's air starts to run low, he contradicts his own instructions for her to conserve her breath and encourages her talk about her own past, which bluntly segues into talk of a lost child. 

One of the big pluses was that the film has been praised for the realism of its premises and its overall adherence to physical principles, despite a number of inaccuracies and exaggerations. According to NASA Astronaut Michael J. Massimino, who took part in two Hubble Space Telescope  Servicing Missions, "nothing was out of place, nothing was missing. There was a one-of-a-kind wirecutter we used on one of my spacewalks and sure enough they had that wirecutter in the movie." Astronaut Buzz Aldrin called the visual effects "remarkable". He adds, "I was so extravagantly impressed by the portrayal of the reality of zero gravity. Going through the space station was done just the way that I've seen people do it in reality. The spinning is going to happen-maybe not quite that vigorous-but certainly we've been fortunate that people haven't been in those situations yet."

I would recommend this to everyone who likes paced story which is fully engaging and thrilling!

Sandra Bullock does do a good job, but she's not giving much in the way of an interesting character or script. Story wise, the whole thing is fairly rote, predictable and unsubstantial. But I came for the spinning and the CGI, and I sure as hell got exactly what I wanted. I just hope Cuaron see's Gravity as a one time experiment, and not as a way forward. 

Also I gotta say, just on a side note, James Cameron you've made 3 films that are leagues beyond this one!!! Then again, that was a while ago.....yikes....

A fascinating blend of opposing extremes, Gravity is gripping and white-knuckle intense from the word go, but also unexpectedly intimate as a character study. Many of its successes are due to an excellent application of sound design, which flutters from loud, echoey destruction to the sudden stillness of panicked breathing amidst the silence of a total vacuum. Outstanding visual effects up the ante a few more notches, expertly visualizing the helpless chaos of a rapidly-compounding disaster in low orbit in a way that's both picturesque and graphically terrifying. That the rules and environments are all so foreign and unfamiliar only makes it easier for the viewing audience to forget that so much of what we're seeing is CG. The underlying moral is more than a little blunt, and a few laws might get bent along the way, but to zero in on those is to ignore the focus of the ride itself. A cinematic roller coaster in the truest sense of the word, it's one of the most physically suspenseful experiences I've ever sat through.

I did not much care for this movie as it presented itself in current, established science pajamas only to make a mockery of astronautics, physics and gravity.   This movie is heavily flawed from the moment the space station is hit and destroyed.  The characters would be very unlikely to survive such an incident in real life, but even if they would, making their way to two other crafts is pure fantasy -- never mind that Sandra Bullock's last harrowing traverse was achieved in a flight suit without any EVA equipment.  It is one thing to invent a starship that travels at warp speed and quite another to throw science to the dogs in a movie that would have its viewers believe in its plot and effects as potentially possible

by Ricky Miller

"Intense" would be an accurate word to describe Alfonso Cuaron's sci-fi epic "Gravity" the new Sandra Bullock film that portrays her as astronaut Ryan Stone, who faces predicaments aplenty in outerspace.
      The usually unnecessary 3-D visuals actually were used well for the storyline and used to the right degree.  "Gravity" is one of those rare instances where the $3 surcharge is worth it.
      The entire movie, however, is not just Bullock flying solo because she has George Clooney's Matt Kowaiski, a fellow astronaut aiding Stone  with some repair in tackling their predicament.  The pair is repairing an unoccupied space station when all of the sudden some floating space junk disrupts everything.
    George Clooney has done the astronaut thing once before in Steven Soderbergh's "Solaris," a slow moving drama that was blasted by critics.  I, however, am part of the minority because I was one of those who didn't dislioke it as much as everyone else.
     Aiding the pair in their plight is the voice of Ed Harris at mission control.  He also played a similar role as a flight commander of the doomed "Apollo 13" mission on the big screen.
      Cuaron, a director with a distinct visual style. seems to jump from project to project.  His last feature was the dystopian drama "Children of Men" headlined by Clive Owen in 2006.  Prior to that he helmed the decent "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azjaban" in 2004.
    Gimmick is the key word the movie studio is using to get people into theater seats.  It works to just the right degree in "Gravity"
Grade:  B-  This review was originally published in The Richland Chronicle 10-15-13...

It's worth seeing at least once.  Gravity is all about the experience and making you feel like you're there, which it really does a good job of for the most part- you feel simultaneously claustrophobic and lost in vastness.  The dialogue however feels so contrived that it's laughable in many parts and I know would become more obvious watching it more than once.  The ending is ridiculously implausible.  If it wasn't for the amazing CGI this would have gotten 1 star from me.

I did not see this in the theaters, and I get the feeling that if you didn't see it in the theaters  and you don't get to see the special effects in 3D on a grand stage...then the movie loses something.  The closest thing I can compare it to is Avatar.  I LOVED Avatar in the theaters.  I called it "The most beautiful film I ever saw".  But I have yet to watch it on the small screen.  I caught a bit of it once, but when you remove that 3rd dimension it loses something.
That's what I think the deal with this movie is.  On the small screen...it is just flat.  And a George Clooney movie that is flat...only exacerbates his flat acting.
I have also seen Sandra Bullock do better.

Gravity is a space thriller starring Sandra Bullock and George Clooney. The film is directed incredibly by Alfonso Cuaron. The visual effects in this movie are outstanding, in my eyes this years Avatar when it comes to effects. The film follows 2 astronauts completing a shuttle mission when debris strikes them, leaving them tethered to each other all alone in space. The acting in the film is of a very high standard, Sandra Bullock pulling an Oscar nomination for her performance. George Clooney is decent, despite not having too much screen time. The movies script is quite strong for the majority however its not a movie that relies on dialogue. What it does rely on is its special effects and direction. The movie is very well shot, watching it the first 5-10 minutes doesn't change shot at all.This is to the credit of the director Alfonso Cuaron. He has a very visual way of directing which is perfect for a movie set in space. The movie does slow down in the middle of the movie but slowly picks up. For a movie about someone floating round space, it's pretty well done.
Final Score
Acting-8.0/10--The performances are pretty solid throughout, especially Bullock
Special Effects-9.5/10--The effects are outstanding in this, should pick up the Oscar for best Visual Effects
Script-6.5/10--Not much dialogue, but it is a movie where you are supposed to feel isolated
Overall Score
Gravity-8-- This is a visual masterpiece, Alfonso Cuaron is the star of the show despite Bullocks performance. Should pick up a few awards.
